content:
Posted: April 23
Product received for free
CrawlGameplayCrawl is a local multiplayer dungeon crawler where it is a race against your friends to be the ultimate hero. Crawl has been in early access for a few years and it might be one of the shining gems to come out of the Early Access void. Crawl is supposed to be a party game where you or one of your friends control the hero and wanders the dungeon alone while the others try to control one of the monsters and try to kill you and halt your progress as the hero so that they can take your place and vice versa. From the start Crawl puts your friends and you in a gladiatorial arena battle where you hammer each other to death before one of you emerges from the rubble caused by the commotion to wander into the dungeons. The other people then become ghosts who can control monsters of varying powers and try to kill the hero at every step he takes. Even here it is a race to get the last hit on the hero so that you can become the hero. It is very frustrating to reduce a hero down to low health by yourself only to see someone else come and take the kill. It does put a lot of pressure on the monsters and they have to be on their guard at every given moment to check out their surroundings.  The other players do not need to become a monster to harm the hero as they can possess things like traps and spring them up at the exact moment to get the kill or throw random objects to hurt the hero. Crawl also gives the player who has been the hero the least times the most powerful monsters to control so the game never feels unfair most of the time unless someone from your party of your monsters take the kill and it is a rage fest all over again. When a hero reaches Level 10, they can activate a sacrificial portal which allows them to face Giant Boss creatures in a bid to escape his fate and the cursed dungeon. The other players control the Boss’s different organs in an almost Power Rangers Megazord kind of way. This great loop of gameplay of Crawl where you keep dying and coming back as the hero makes Crawl one of the best couch co op games in recent memory.As the hero Crawl feels like a typical dungeon crawler RPG where you hack, slash, loot, dodge and earn XP to level up. There are a variety of weapons and spells for the player to use as the Hero and while there are you usual inane weapons which don’t feel anywhere close to some others, there is quite some interesting loot present in Crawl. The game as the hero plays like you would expect but it is the great unknown of the pleothera of monsters waiting behind the next door that is the great draw of Crawl. As the ghost you have a lot of options to choose from a variety of monsters who have different tiers which require Wraith to unlock more powerful monsters. The monsters are quite obviously different from each other in very unique ways and while it might seem unfair, it gives the lowliest of players the strongest of monsters to have his own time in the glory.The AI for solo play in Crawl is competent but nowhere near as fun as you will have with your friends. It is completely worth a try for its single play but do make a reminder to invite your friends over later for this one. There is no online play to speak of and considering the gameplay, it is probably for the best too. Crawl feels incredibly polished and the game runs really smooth at any given instance of time.VisualsAs far as pixelated art goes, Crawl takes the cake. It has a gorgeous art style which somehow makes even the blood and gore on the screen pretty neat. This is a game famous for spawning countless GIF’s and there are more to come from here. Some of the monster designs are truly incredible and some of them never fail to make you laugh. The game looks incredibly good and there is nothing quite like it.SoundCrawl has an incredible sound design which compliments its gameplay and visual aesthetics really well. The sound effects are solid and set the mood perfectly. There is little voice acting from the narrator but whatever there is, it is done really well.OverallCrawl is one of the best couch co op game to have ever graced my screen and there is no two way about it. It is one of the best examples of early access being done right and there is nothing quite like a Crawl party when it really gets going, Crawl works completely fine as a single player game too and there is a lot of content here to justify the price tag but you should definitely get Crawl if you want a solid game to enjoy with your friends.Rating: 95/100This review was brought to you by SaveorQuit. For more amazing reviews, previews and gaming news visit: SaveorQuit[saveorquit.com]

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2
Early Access Review
								Imagine finding someone on a cold concrete floor, the room devoid of any windows or open doors.  As he struggles to his feet he notices three of his best friends making the same discovery in the room.  Suddenly, as if a product of his own confusion, a voice shouts in from above telling him that only one of them will survive.  Scrambling to find something useful on the ground, he realized they must have heard that same voice!  Brought back to his feet by the safety of a knife, he notices there is only one left and his back is turned.  The knife is plunged into his back and he immediately falls to his knees with him in dismay.  Regretful thoughts and sobbing are interrupted by the voice again, “Get up, death is no means to an end in this vile place,” and to his uneasy comfort, his friends were floating above him in spirit.	The mechanics of this game have created an incredibly balanced gameplay that is easy for anyone to get into, built on top of a wonderfully themed visual and auditory experience.  Now begins the intrepid narrative through the ever-changing procedural dungeons of Crawl.  This unique four-player split-screen game by the Australian studio Powerhoof starts you off against all your friends (or surprisingly intelligent AI) in a one-hit-to-kill brawl to decide who the hero will be first.  When you are not the hero, you are a ghost that may float around the map getting into whatever he or she may like.  They could inhabit furniture and throw it, they could command traps to aim and activate, they could interact with pictures and holes in the walls, and of course, summon and inhabit upgradable monsters on pentagrams.  Once a monster, or even a trap or furniture kills the hero, that ghost will take his place leading the exploration.  The goal in this game is to reach level 10 and challenge the player-controlled boss.  	The cohesive design of the auditory and visual aspects of this game are really the biggest things that set it apart from others.  They had decided on a very low-resolution pixel art type of sprite style, which being paired with the chip-tune style of music creates a beautiful modern take on this classic style.  The title screen and name screen even say “Insert Coin” instead of “Press Start” and only allow you to enter three-character names like an old arcade box.  Many tiny details have been added to the game, proving how much time and dedication it must have taken to build such a piece.  From random seeming pixel glitches on the menu screen paired with auditory glitches, to rich item descriptions, to screen shake.  There is even a narrator at the beginning of rounds that tells the story slightly different every time.  If you are the type of person that is overwhelmed by this art style, which I will admit is pretty common when you first start playing, I urge you to play for a while and really give the game a good shot.	Everyone I have showed this game to seems a little overwhelmed and intimidated at first, just due to the amount of things happening on screen at all times.  The presumption that you will not be good at this game at first, however, is one that could not be further from the truth.  Even if you cannot kill the hero and lead the charge, your monsters will continue to level up as the current hero does.  Inversely, if you are very good at this game and spend the whole time playing as the hero you may have good weapons, but your monsters will be weak and it will be significantly harder to become the hero again.  Given the multiplayer mechanics, the balancing aspects of this game seemed to have just come together inherently.  It feels so very natural to play, and often times, will create some very unexpected outcomes.  The bosses require the ghost players to work together and coordinate their attacks; otherwise it will be all too easy for the hero.  *********************Warning: Spoilers*************************One boss has an arm that fires sludge that will slow down and damage the hero.  The other arm fires bubbles that will trap the hero and make the final boss weapon much easier to hit.  The last weapon is an enormous eye laser that moves very slowly, but if the other teammates have done their jobs correctly, it will make short work of any level hero.  The other boss is a three-headed elemental dragon that has somewhat similar mechanics, but requires a different strategy.  There is an NPC in this boss fight that heals the player, which means the dragons best bet is to stay between the hero and the health.  As interesting and fun as these bosses are, more bosses would add a lot more variety to each dungeon adding much more replay value to this game.********************End Spoilers************************** 	After playing “Crawl” with lots of friends it has easily found its way into my top five games.  The gameplay is chaotic, and challenging, and terribly competitive.  The overall style and design of the game makes it feel like a complete new artistic world to explore.  However, as full and entertaining as this game is, it is only in early access. It is not even finished yet, so go on steam and watch their wonderfully interesting trailers and support the designers at Powerhoof by getting your copy.TL;DRAwesome Game, go buy it and beat up your friends

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								I bought this game a couple days ago and I have to say I am very dissapointed... in the obnoxious, trout-bearded tacowallets I call friends. What I expected to be a competitive and fun game to play with others turned out to be the biggest troll-fest to which I've ever been subjected. If they were in human form, they'd allow me to kill them without a fight just so they could have the satisfaction of teaming up on me. I climbed level after level, giving them precious vitae to evolve into the most powerful BS monsters I've ever faced in any game. I can't count how many times I was reduced to a puddle of blood by a giant death-beam eyeball with wings, or forced to endure a small room full of traps because they just HAD to drop a single blob as I was about to walk through the door. I was the only one able to make it to the boss battles with my humanity intact, but I soon discovered that this was just a complex ruse to make me use up all the portal attempts and have all memory of my character erased from history by getting barfed on by my friends' three headed dragon.But as long as your co-op parters aren't complete jerks, you'll enjoy this well-polished game.10/10 would get trolled again.

 TL:DR - This game is truly a masterpiece, featuring challenges, voice acting, and the end of friendships.  Crawl. Crawl to your fridge, because my♥♥♥♥♥is numb the solid hours I could waste playing this game. I gotta be honest, this game is super intense, and I still keep mixing up the Z&X buttons, but I can't change them, because then I'd get even more mixed up, how does that work? I don't know!  I've always been a fan of pixel graphics in games, and this one excels my desire for such that. Of course, this isn't Online Multiplayer, but Local, so if I did have friends, this would likely end friendships. Regardless, I'm having quite a fun time on my own with this game, and those REALLY annoying bots. After a good 1.3 hours, I figured out how to kill that giant statue♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, I mean - I hit him once before I got destroyed, but I figured it out at least, it's progress..  This game is pretty dope. I plan on spending a lot more hours on it, and becoming better at it, maybe. There's some amazing voice acting in this game, which more than surprised me, and it offers insane challenges within itself, which is rather new to me, actual challenge in a game. I yet, have not faced loss, but neither win - and both sound pretty fun if I'm honest, in order to improve for a game in the future, I figure. This game is beautifully made, and the developers knew what they were doing to craft such a masterpiece. I am truly in love with how this was made, it's style, and the challenges that arise whilst in game.

Early Access Review
								This review is long overdue.  I bought this game quite a few months ago since I have a huge interest in neo-arcade games and I was not dissapointed.  This game has it all:-fantastic 4 player party experience that leaves you yelling at each other and getting worked up over your clutch kills to steal the hero role-The story telling you get at the begining of the game is absolutely perfect.  The second the intro happened, I was immediately pulled in and knew I would love this game-The music and sounds effects are fantastic and really pulls me into the experience even more.  I'm not exactly sure who did the music and sound design but they definitely did an amazing job.  It really captures the intensity and sets the world perfectly.-This game even saves your initials like an old NBA Jam game!  It feels great to again be able to have the name A.S.S.These are just a few points that doesn't even do this game justice.  It is an amazing game!  My friends and I would promote getting this game any day of the week! The only negative thing about this game is the lack of online play.  But with that said, the game isn't really designed to play online since it is much better to play with friends in the room!Overall, Buy this ♥♥♥♥ing masterpiece!Even the trailer gets me pumped up.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								I wanted this game as soon as I saw the trailers, and I wasn't disappointed. In fact, I've played it everyday since I got it. It's a fast-paced game with great music, atmosphere, gameplay, and a lot of challenge without too steep a curve. I have only played with AI so far, and I still have a lot of fun. They feel like proper opponents, and help set the illusion that you're playing with people.I first used keyboard controls. They're alright; I wouldn't advise you slouch or curl up while playing though, as there's a lot of rapid button-pushing involved and that'll make your hands cramp up very quickly. I now use an iBuffalo Classic USB gamepad; the same goes for it, although that might just be because it's a new gadget and hasn't been broken in yet. Both control sets work great! Word to the wise, though: As of now, you can't adjust the gamepad controls in the main menu; you have to start a game and then use the controls menu that appears immediately after.The developers are still working out the kinks, I imagine, and they're adding new content all the time. The brief story-like introductions have some great variety to them, and there's nothing more awesome than going through all the new monsters, weapons, and items you unlock after every game. I have no complaints!

content:
Posted: April 11
												Crawl is one of the most fun local multiplayer games I have ever played, with a unique mechanic whereby players take control of the dungeon and become the hero by killing him. The hero is more powerful than the monsters, so the non-hero players are forced to co-operate to whittle down his health, but once he's at low health that spirit of co-operation goes out the window and everyone is trying to land the final blow for themselves. This game's balance is extremely tight, barring a few exceptions (bows are the worst starting weapon in the game by far) and it's always a blast to play since the games aren't too long.The mid-game is where Crawl truly shines, as the monster players have gained enough power to defeat the hero and he has yet to gain the powerful late-game equipment that would allow him to defeat such threats. At this point the game becomes a race, where you want to grab enough upgrades to be able to take on the bosses, but not spend so much time in the dungeon that you die and lose your spot as hero.My only real complaint about Crawl is that I wish there were just a couple more bosses, as for most of the early access period there were only two, and now they have come to full release adding on just one last boss. The boss fights are fun, but with such a limited pool they get old fast, with optimal attack patterns that are easy to counter as the hero.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								A lot of fun already! With Lovecraftian horror and 8-bit pixel art, a couch competitive 3v1 dungeon crawler emerges from the depths.How it worksI've never played a competitive game with this mechanic before. A brief matchup at the beginning of each game determines who the "human" player is, and who the "monster" players are. The human player traverses the dungeon, looking for the stairs to the next level. The monster players control spirits who float around the room with the ability to possess traps, spawn slimes, and summon controllable demons for the purpose of killing the human player. If the human player dies, the monster player who landed the fatal blow assumes the role of the human hero while the former human player joins the ranks of the ghosts. The amount of monsters you kill as the human hero determines who wins the game, with a levelling system that gives boosts to overall health. Monster earn a separate class of EXP which can be used to upgrade their demons to even more powerful monstrosities. Human players also have the opportunity starting at level 10 to fight a challenging dungeon boss picked at random.What it needsThere should be a system to upgrade peak monsters' base attributes, though, as a handicap for less experienced players. I already love the balancing system though. Also, at this point, the music is very limited and gets pretty repetitive. Finally, attack controls feel a little gummy and could use work before you stop walking away from the game with bloody thumbs.In conclusionBuy this game if you love dungeon crawlers, rogue-lites, and are looking for a very new twist on a classic genre to challenge your friends with. Don't have friends? Pick this up when it's on sale, you can still play the game with up to 3 AI players who range from competent to outright ruthless, but this game really shines the brightest when your opponent is on the couch next to you.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is great! I'll try to avoid giving out the same details as everyone else, but the praise is well-deserved, this game does a ton of things right! Now, since all the peeps below me have given the game the good stuff, I'll say all the bad stuff I have come across. Firstly, the rooms look nice, they really do, but they all look the same, their shapes are different, and that does determine life or death in circumstances, but still, change it up a bit please. Secondly, the game could use some balancing, the starting human starts off at  major disadvantage to the monsters when they inevitably fall and become a monster, they're a super-weak monster (this is an early access, so this'll be fixed sooner or later.). The controls are also less fit for a keyboard as you can only aim in 4 directions, this can be fixed with a controller, but not all of us have those, and it often makes the game a tad more difficult when aiming. The boss also has an unskippable cutscene which after a while made the boss look kind of...Cute, in a derpy fashion...(IGNORE THAT.). Besides the above, this game is a great example of early-access done right, and its dev's are fun guys. I highly suggest you get it if you have friends locally near you, if not, it may not be the best, but you can play with bots, who are pretty smart, and can become stupid if you turn down the difficulty.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								Crawl is a great game I give it 4 out of 5 stars for the state its in as of 08/07/2015 and let me tell you why. Its pretty much like its not in early access. What I like about the game is that there are a lot of possibilities in the battle of who is to win. I like how there are only three chances you get to win the game. With that being said, anyone over the level of 10 could go for it when they reach the shrine. As of right now there are two bosses you can either be or fight which is randomly chosen for you when you activate the shrines. Either you or the other 3 players (depending on who activates the shrine) become part of the three parts of the boss, and you have to try to defeat the boss while the others use the boss to defeat you. Anyone can fail twice fighting the boss battles. The third time whoever fails will ultimately lose the game and the other players win in a first, second, third basis.(The loser being 4th) I also like the dynamic of there is one hero and the others are ghosts vying for the life of the hero and use forms of monsters to try to steal the life of the hero and become him. All an all this is a great game and I cannot wait for the full version. What I would like to see in the full version is a database for all that you unlock like a lore, just like Risk Of Rain. And also I really hope and pray they create multiplayer because that would make it 5 stars in my opinion.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								Everyone needs to play this game. Even though it is in early access, it has very little bugs. ( so little I haven't spotted one)The main goal is to level up to ten and defeat the boss at the end. Sounds simple until you have a three friends over with the same goal. This game is fun alone and with your friends. The fighting is simple and easy to use. ( for both ghosts and humans) The game is also very balanced. You also unlock more items for your next round. I haven't unlocked everything yet, but everytime I do unlock something (you unlock at least one thing every game) I want to see it and test it out. This game has a ton of items to choose from. Making it very easy to fit your play style. One more thing I love is the "gods" you can pick from. The gods is like your class for your hero. They give you three monsters and a passive to help your ghost or hero. In the end of every level you can level up your monsters.In the end, I am so pumped to see every update, to unlock every new thing, to destroy my friends in a battle with all odds against you. This game puts such a smile on my face. If this game was finished right here, I wouldn't be mad, this game is already fun, with almost no bugs.96/100

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is one of the best games of 2014. A wonder take on king of the hill, one player is the adventurer delving a dungeon, the other three players are ghosts that possess creatures of the darkness and control traps, all vying to be the one to land the killing blow on the adventurer to steal his humanity. Die, kill, die again, try and take back your humanity and then slay the boss monster guarding the exit. It's a hell of a romp for couch gaming.Con if you don't have friends that will come over and game: no online at present. The local multiplayer aspect adds a great deal to the experience.The latest update for 9/26 added new monsters, deities, and balance changes. Scorpion OP, demon lord sucks.

												One of the best couch co-opition multiplayer games, arcade style dungeon crawling where your 'friends' take control of the monsters and traps inside the dungeons you crawl through and ♥♥♥♥ you up till it's one of their turns to get ♥♥♥♥ed up. content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								Short version:Get it if you have 1 to 3 friends, (so, a total of 4 peeps,) that love playing new types of games on a couch.Longer version:Couch Conflict games are great but tend to fall into a very small selection of catagories.A large number are 1 screen platformers.Another swathe are 1 screen "asteroids" based twin stick shooters.Within these 2 large pools there are some stellar gems, a lot of winners, a few minor tweaks and innovations and a lot of "others" that don't really distinguish them selves well.For the most part, if you have a handful of entries from these groups in your library, you'll have the basics covered and dipping back in too the pools probably won't net you anything wonderfully different.So it's always exciting when clever people come up with something that feel radically different with out over complicating what you seek out from these experiances.Nighogg is a great example of this idea, and if you're looking at Crawl as a multiplayer couch gamer, you probably already know about the joys of that.What Crawl offers is different again... and does take a minute more to absorb, but after that you will be drinking in a game that takes the head to head nature of this genre and mixes in a brilliant and ever changing landscape of all vs 1 and and great "begining-middle-end" arc in each session.If you have your basic couch conflict games covered, Get Nidhogg and get this and you'll have a great little menu to pick from.Nighog for instantly accessable gaming at snack like speed.Twin stick arenas and 1 screen platformers for experiances with a hair more length and variable substance.Crawl for a solid hunk of entertainment that still leaves room for multiple sessions.(Oh and Mount your friends for dessert... because it's fruity and lite) :D

content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								     Gameplay is great, even with bots it gets competiteve and faced paced. Bots are very competiteve in the first place, and i cant even imagine fighting them on hard mode. The monsters evolve after each floor, getting tougher and tougher, and eventuallly, they will kill you, you only get "xp" (or vitae, as its called ingame)  to evolve your monsters if the other players level up, so it has a massive competition side to it, if you survive the whole floor, and not be killed once, then you probably wont be able to evole your monsters. So what do you get? The other players are getting the advantage... but not really, you have weapons, swords and bows and javelins/spears to fight them off, some quicker some slower but more damage, there are many, many many many weapons to this game to kill your undead enemies, atleast, i think there are. (plus theres assassins blades... so thats cool :D)Each time you finish a game, more content gets added (it of course tells you what once you beat it) like more weapons, traps, gods and more, so if theres not enough content for you, dont you worry there will be more.So your a monster and you kill the player, whoever got the last blow turns into the human, and you got it, what do you do? go to the blacksmith shop, or find it, because every time you hit the player, you earn "blood" which you can give to a statue in the blacksmith shop. the statue is happy from the blood you spilled, and rewards you, with money, that you can use for weapons or purchase a "spell" that replaces your dodge roll.So this game offers much, and is definatley worth ten bucks, infact i think that is a lower price than what this game offers, and the fact this game is going to ofer more in the future... well thats just great.So welcome to the dungeons, Crawler

								It is already one of the best couch (semi-)coop games you can get IMO, even though it’s in early access. The game offers a whole new experience: in-game friends turn to enemies and the other way round.Also it never felt like a beta, it seemed very well thought-out from the get-go and now they are adding new content and balance it a bit more, a flagship early access game if you ask me.At our first session we’ve played the game 6 hours straight without noticing the time going by. So I’d suggest you’d play it with “gamers”. But if your friends are hooked they are hooked for good and will be as excited about the game as I am.Aside from that It’s the most fun I’ve had with a game in a long time. I’ve played it 13h by now and it would have been much longer if I had more people to play it with. Go try it out! :)

content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								Well, I saw this game at the bottom of Steam's New Releases list. I'd never seen or heard of the game before, but that pixel art drew me in close enough to click on it. Boy am I glad I did.In Crawl you play as a ghost trying to murder your living friend, or a hero trying to survive your dead friends' onslaught. Hero's can explore the map, break things, buy weapons at the shop, open chests, and attempt to kill the monsters your friends summoned and are controlling. Ghosts can summon monsters when inside a pentagram, possess various kinds of traps throughout the dungeon, spawn slimes if they've collected enough ghost fluff (or whatever it is...), or even take control of a boss the hero is trying to kill.So, the game starts as one of you randomly chosen as the first hero, who goes about the dungeon exploring rooms, and fending off friends who actively try to kill him. "Why?" You may ask. Well, the ghost that lands the killing blow on the hero regains their humanity and becomes the new hero, while the dead hero becomes a ghost. And the fight continues.The hero progresses through the dungeon, leveling up by collecting experience from slain monsters. They can buy new weapons, which range from broadswords, to crossbows, to dual throwing knives; special abilities, which allow you to replace your starting dodge roll with better dodging abilities, beserker rage, and lasers; as well as potions and apparel that grant permenant effects like Dragon's Blood that lowers your max health, but makes you deal more damage. My personal favorite, Golem's Blood, which causes you to mave 10% slower, but raises your max health by 40%. Acid cursed rings that causes you to loose pools of acid every time you get hit to damage your attacker, or the shield that floats around you blocking damage altogether. Need some more gold? Cash in all the blood you took from the hero as a ghost to earn a ton of extra cash.Once a hero reaches level 10 they can challenge the boss. The boss is also controlled by the ghosts, who work together to keep the hero from winning the game, because the boss slayer automatically wins first place. If defeated, the hero returns with low life, sure to die within the next few moments.Now, here's the catch. You can only challenge a boss three times before the portal permenently closes. If the hero loses here, not only do they automatically get last place, but they lose that character forever. Normally, even if your the ghosts and lose when someone beats the boss, your character profile is saved, and you can use them again next time. (with all abilities and weapons reset of course) Not if you lose to the boss the third time. If that happens, your gone forever. This allows you to sort of keep a win streak, or stay-alive streak rather. I can't wait to see how the devs use this in the future.Now, heros can level up, so how do the ghosts compensate? They can evolve their monsters. When a hero levels up, each ghost gets Vitae that they can spend evolving monsters when the hero completes a floor. There's lots of monster evolution chains and you can unlock even more. Before you start, each player chooses a deity to worship, which changes the kinds of monsters that are avalible to you as a ghost. Staying the hero for too long will yeild very powerful enemies for you friends, but stay a ghost for too long and you'll never have a shot at beating the game. The longer you stay a ghost, the more powerful your monters become compared to your friends, and the more powerful your monsters, the higher chance you have at landing the killing blow and becomeing the hero. You see? It's all ingeniously ballanced.Yes I can recomend the game right now. Although there's only one boss and and a few deities. The devs are working on more. This is really good for an early access game.On a side note, This game is Lovecraftian as heck. And I love it for that.Only one issue with the game. It's local multiplayer only at this point. Not that I have a big problem with that, but...Now all I need is 3 people willing to sit around a computer screen to play with me :p8/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
Early Access Review
Platform: Ubuntu 14.04 with mid-high specs (see profile for details). Runs absolutely perfectly, with brilliant gamepad support using steamos-dkms xpad drivers. I have a soft spot for local multiplayer, and so I tend to add to basket as soon as I see a game tagged in this way. This review starts by saying that Crawl is potentially one of the best local multiplayer games I've played for a while. I played this game last night with my sister and parents (3 gamepads and myself, the unfortunate soul with the keyboard). I know we'll play again tonight, its that kind of game. Each time you play it begins like this, someone starts up the game, everyone taps their respective controller and occupies a slot, which the game cutely refers to as inserting a coin. You enter a 3 letter name, or choose a previously used one. Then you select a deity to worship (as of writing this review there are 3 deities; two instantly available and 1 unlockable). Your choice of deity decides what sort of beasts you can manifest yourself as to hinder the current hero. The game begins.The current hero is selected randomly from the up-to-4 players, and attempts to crawl through the dungeon as far as possible, amassing gold, buying new items and buffs. All the while, the non-hero players attempt to kill the hero by either manifesting as monsters by activating pentagrams that are one the floor of some rooms, "going-poltergeist" and possessing traps or turrets, or summoning slimes that they can stockpile by collecting dust. The non-hero player that kills the hero player gets to continue where the previous hero player left off, albeit without his buffs and items, these have to be collected individually. The object of the game, which you can only progress towards during your time as the hero, is to reach at least level ten so that you can open the boss portal, and defeat the boss. Aside from this the game has intervals everytime a player descends to a lower floor. During these intervals players receive vitae points for everytime an opposing player levelled up on the previous floor. They can use these points to evolve their selection of beasts, making them stronger and a greater threat to opposing heroes. Why I like it so muchThe game offers a simple but very replayable mechanic. The non-hero players work together to try and kill the current hero, but ultimately want to beat the others to land the final blow and secure precious flesh-and-blood hero time. The current hero works to improve their items, spells and buffs so that they can fight off opposing players for longer. The struggle is fast paced, skillful and very fun. After level 10 players have the chance to nab the winner's position by choosing to fight the boss, but they only get so many chances, otherwise they finish last. As more bosses are implemented into the game, the risk of entering the boss portal will become even more interesting; what if its a boss you don't like and you only have one chance left? Maybe you should level further? But what if one of your opponents goes through? So so fun.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
Early Access Review
Platform: Ubuntu 14.04 with mid-high specs (see profile for details). Runs absolutely perfectly, with brilliant gamepad support using steamos-dkms xpad drivers. I have a soft spot for local multiplayer, and so I tend to add to basket as soon as I see a game tagged in this way. This review starts by saying that Crawl is potentially one of the best local multiplayer games I've played for a while. I played this game last night with my sister and parents (3 gamepads and myself, the unfortunate soul with the keyboard). I know we'll play again tonight, its that kind of game. Each time you play it begins like this, someone starts up the game, everyone taps their respective controller and occupies a slot, which the game cutely refers to as inserting a coin. You enter a 3 letter name, or choose a previously used one. Then you select a deity to worship (as of writing this review there are 3 deities; two instantly available and 1 unlockable). Your choice of deity decides what sort of beasts you can manifest yourself as to hinder the current hero. The game begins.The current hero is selected randomly from the up-to-4 players, and attempts to crawl through the dungeon as far as possible, amassing gold, buying new items and buffs. All the while, the non-hero players attempt to kill the hero by either manifesting as monsters by activating pentagrams that are one the floor of some rooms, "going-poltergeist" and possessing traps or turrets, or summoning slimes that they can stockpile by collecting dust. The non-hero player that kills the hero player gets to continue where the previous hero player left off, albeit without his buffs and items, these have to be collected individually. The object of the game, which you can only progress towards during your time as the hero, is to reach at least level ten so that you can open the boss portal, and defeat the boss. Aside from this the game has intervals everytime a player descends to a lower floor. During these intervals players receive vitae points for everytime an opposing player levelled up on the previous floor. They can use these points to evolve their selection of beasts, making them stronger and a greater threat to opposing heroes. Why I like it so muchThe game offers a simple but very replayable mechanic. The non-hero players work together to try and kill the current hero, but ultimately want to beat the others to land the final blow and secure precious flesh-and-blood hero time. The current hero works to improve their items, spells and buffs so that they can fight off opposing players for longer. The struggle is fast paced, skillful and very fun. After level 10 players have the chance to nab the winner's position by choosing to fight the boss, but they only get so many chances, otherwise they finish last. As more bosses are implemented into the game, the risk of entering the boss portal will become even more interesting; what if its a boss you don't like and you only have one chance left? Maybe you should level further? But what if one of your opponents goes through? So so fun.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've really liked this game. So far I've been playing it for about an hour and here are some of my first impressions:Gameplay: The gameplay itself is very sleek and smooth. Crawl resembles that of a button mashing arcade figher, which isn't a bad thing. There are two buttons you use to attack (primary and special) which just feels very satisfying. The concept itself is original as well, and that's something I haven't seen in quite a while. It's almost like a multiplayer dungeon crawler King of the Hill RPG. You battle your friends who are attemtping to kill you in order to revive themselves as humans and collect randomized dungeon loot along the way. If you or any of your friends finish off the human, they revive and then have their shot at completing the level. As the ghost characters, you take control of items and can summon monsters which you can evolve. At a certain point along the way you gain enough experience to fight the boss battle. Admittedly, the boss battle did come a little quickly and I had beaten the game before I knew it. However I noticed I unlocked a few items, so I know that coupled with the randomly generated levels means replayability is implied.Art Style: I'm also a fan of this art style which is what first caught my eye. The animations are smooth and the characters are well drawn. I've never been the type to complain about pixel art as if it were an excuse to "real art"; it looks great. The only issue is I find myself backing away from the monitor to get the full view of some text which is otherwise a little difficult to read from up close.Music: About what you would expect, pretty catchy but has a few points where it appears to stutter.This game is in early stages, and it looks promising. So if it's good now, it can only get better.It's only $10 right now so there's really nothing to lose by giving this a try.I suppose the only thing I'd like to see a network multiplayer. And I understand the naivity of most people who make that statement and don't understand that networking isn't an easy task, but I could see this game being a blast at LAN parties and with friends who don't want to crowd around one screen or use mutliple controllers.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								After a couple hours of gameplay, this is easily one of the most addicting games I've ever played. It's a fairly simple dungeon-crawler, yet it is very enjoyable. Very old-school, which is something I appreciate. In each round there are 4 players. Of these players, 3 are ghosts and 1 is a human. As a ghost, the objective is to work together with the other ghosts to slay the human. This can be done by turning into enemies, activating traps, and summoning blobs. When a human dies, the ghost who landed the killing blow then becomes the human. The goal is to stay human long enough to become level 10, after which you must find a portal and defeat a boss.Pros and Cons:+ Simple to learn, yet hard to master+ Very addictive+ Great multiplayer+ Nonstop action, monster or human+ Well-balanced mechanics (monster strength, health, etc.)+ Old-school, classic video game feeling+ Well randomized, even with small details+ Lots of weapons+ BE THE MONSTER- No online multiplayer- Only 2 bossesAs you can see, I have few complaints about the game. Overall, it is a well-made and very enjoyable game.

								Crawl is a fun and new take on the classic dungeon crawler. However, instead of having a party of heroes, venturing into a dusty pit of doom, you have one hero and a party of evil ghosts, trying to kill him and thus take his place as the hero. It's hours of fun for the price and the originality of the gameplay together with the charming blocky art style has already made this one of my favourite local multiplayer games on Steam.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								After a year and a half of sifting through the boring, uninteresting titles on greenlight (I've viewed almost 1,000 titles), I finally stumbled across this huge surprise! The concept combined with the incredebly well done trailer and the fact it took less than 24 hours to be greenlit (not to mention, only two people were on this project) hooked me right from the start! I waited in anticipation for roughly 7 months (other people have waited for 2-ish years), so you'd expect that there would be A TON of hype, and I'm telling you right now, that all of that hype did not exceed that which this game deserved. To be completely honest, this is the most fun I've gotten out of ANY multiplayer game ever. This is an early access game, so it isn't finished (even though it's pretty much flawless in my opinion). They're going to be adding so much more content that I think may surpass the $9.99 value (which I feel is a perfect price for how much content there is currently). I urge you to consider supporting these two fine gentlemen in their quest to make the ultimate game (which may increase the chances of online multiplayer).EDIT: Just thought I should add a few things based on what i've learned and also on the new update that came out a while ago.I think it's imperative that everyone knows that the devs are actively interacting with the community on a weekly basis and sometimes more often than that. They are two very well mannered gentlemen that love to hear your ideas and definitely take every one of them into consideration. They actively post updates on development weekly and, like I said before, sometimes more often than that. There is promise of a trove of content that I'm pretty confident will come!This update that came out in September practically doubled the content and they almost nailed the ballance on some of the earlier monsters from the first early access build. Just a few ballance issues with a few monsters from this new update need to be worked out, but that's hardly a concern of mine with devs as dilegent as these.I should also note that the community that has been formed around this game is quite lovely and the people in it are very creative! Right now (Nov-december 2014) there's tons of excitement surrounding the release of a new update coming towards the end of December that includes a brand new boss and some other valuable content and the devs have maintained 100% transparency as far as their progress on the implimentation and testing of said boss and content. (aside from surprises that they wish to keep a secret). So you can just head on over to the forums and check that out. Drop in some suggestions if you'd like! (aside from Online Multiplayer, the devs have heard that over and over and over again) We'd love to have you!EDIT EDIT: A lot has happened! A new boss has been added, new gods, more secrets, a new environment, and a wealth of monsters. They've added game changing mechanics and features that really change up where the game goes and can really shift the outcome of a match. They revamped the color pallet so it looks really nice and pretty now. Barney and Dave have really pulled it out in these last few months and have done nothing but improve the game and its value!EDIT: Been a while. content:
Posted: January 15
Early Access Review
								Definitely one of my favorite local-coop games and nearly the only one, I play alone, too, from time to time. It's always fun and gets more interesting from run to run, because the game being still in early access, it's getting better and more polished, too. What I really like, you always unlock some new items etc. after a run, sometimes you don't think, they won't change too much, but after the next run you are deeply satisfied.OK: the gameplay: you and your friend/enemies try to get enough experience to defeat a big monster boss. What makes the game interesting: there is only one player that plays a living human being, the other ones are ghosts that can possess different objects/traps in rooms to kill the human or conjure monsters, at certain points. When the human dies, one of the others, a real player or the computer, can have the body of the human. You fight from floor to floor, earning gold, to buy interesting weapons and other upgrades at shops, one shop each floor.I really love the controls, at first they felt clumsy and out of touch, but this is part oft the charme of the game, that it is rather difficult to aim et cetera: just brillant! Because everything in the game fits to each other. I love the retro graphics/pixel art/the music/sound, everything. Only one thing would be a negative aspect for me: there are far too less different end-bosses: there are only two of them.And that makes the end-fights a little bit boring and repetive. I hope for much more (at least five?)!Thanks!If you want a game that gives you deep satisfaction and is perfect for killing some time here and then, without getting addicted, but always to be remembered in the best possible way: give it a chance, it's worth its money!

content:
Posted: April 22
Product received for free
												Well guys, it's 97% positive, so I'm just another small voice in a huge choir of praises, but here goes:Video, in case you'd rather watch


YouTube™ Video: Crawl - Indie Game Reviews 2017 - Backstab your friends! 

			Views: 105		

			Welcome back to Indie Game Reviews 2017, hosted by ShortGameReviews.com! Today we are going to take a look at the game called "Crawl", a dungeon-crawler with strong local multiplayer!		

About the GameCrawl is a peculiar game. It recently left early access, entering the fully released stage. The game’s idea is really original: four players (either bots or humans) are playing at the same time. One of them gets the role of dungeon explorer, going through the dungeon. Other take the roles of ghosts, who can spawn monsters or possess the traps across the rooms. If someone manages to kill the dungeon explorer, he takes his role, while recently deceased player becomes a ghost. The player who manages to get level 10 and kill the dungeon boss wins.The Good•	Really innovative and fun gameplay: there’s also no downtime for anyone, because all players influence the game in a way. It’s like telling a story from two different points of view•	Lots of content and variety: different bosses, monsters, weapons and items. As you play more games, you get more unlocks, diversifying the randomized gameplay even further•	AI is really good•	The game has its own style: the pixel art is well aligned and fits the theme wellThe Bad•	A bit of a snowballing tend to happen. If one player levels up while playing explorer, other players (ghosts) are getting stronger monsters. Technically, that tends to even out the disadvantages (weaker players have stronger monsters -> statistically they tend to kill explorer more and take its role) as the game progresses. But if weaker player gets the role of explorer – he still has to fight the strong monsters of at least two other ghosts which often won’t be in his favor. During the midgame this gap is felt the most, but then it evens out if the game drags on a bit. That’s really the only drawback I can name.•	No online multiplayer: the game could really benefit from it.•	Also, minor thing, but I could not switch active display on my machine (could not move the game to second screen). The option to do this is there, but it did not work if I changed it.SummaryThe game is good in singleplayer, because AI can use the surroundings well and both control and combat the monsters skillfully. However, Crawl shines brightest when played with friends: the hot-cold relationship that turns upside down when someone takes control of the explorer (and the old foe, in turn, becomes somewhat your friend) makes up for a lot of funny and exciting moments. The content unlocks also makes it really replayable. Overall, it’s a solid game with original premise and I highly recommend it.

Posted: August 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								      Wow, what a surprise. I'm not usually one to pick up early access games as I would prefer to play a finished project, but after seeing this on the Humble store, I  immediately fell in love with the pixel/glitch art style. I checked out the gameplay video and decided to give it a chance.      Crawl starts up as if it's an old school arcade game, asking you to insert coin and enter you initials. Up to four players can play via couch co-op (no online unfotunately, but I think the fast paced gameplay lends itself better to local co-op) using keyboard, mouse or controllers. One player starts as the human character advancing through the dungeon collecting money, loot or finding the exit to the dungeon. The other three player take control of ghosts who can summon creatures or possess traps in the dungeon with the purpose of destroying the human character. Once a ghost player has killed the human player, they become the human. End game happens once a human character destroys the main boss.      As you progress, your character levels up and can buy weapons and equipment that change the way the game is played. In between levels, you can upgrade the monster creatures you send out as a ghost, making the game more difficult as you progress. It's very nicely balanced and I never felt like one player was too strong or weak against other players. While this game is meant to be played with multiple players, I found single player with bots surprisingly challenging, and at times forgot I was playing against the computer.      I highly recomend Crawl if your looking for a frantic couch co-op game to play with your friends, or just looking for a fast paced arcade style game to play by yourself. With the added promise from the developers of more creatures, dungeons, and items to be added in the future, as well as the $10 price tag, you really can't go wrong with this one.

Posted: August 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								We’ve all played RPG’s before with friends at our side, but what happens when your friends control the monsters instead? Developed by the two man team over at Powerhoof, Crawl is a local co-op dungeon crawler for up to four players, and provides the answer to that very question.In a rather interesting turn of events, one of you controls the hero, slaying monsters, gaining levels, and buying loot, while the other 3 players use ghosts to possess traps or summon monsters with the simple goal of killing you to become the hero instead. The point of Crawl is to survive long enough to reach level 10, then activating a portal to the final boss encounter. The player that reaches and defeats the final boss first wins the game.If you have local friends who frequent your house, Crawl is an insanely good time. Its short 30-minute games, combined with its accessible pick-up-and-play control scheme, make it ideal for parties or for larger groups of people to pass the controllers around. However, if you’re running solo, you’ll most likely grow tired of fighting the A.I. rather quickly and there isn’t anything to do after that.Full review: http://wp.me/p2go2D-4Gd

Even with only one boss and a medium range of monsters, this game has kept me Crawling with excitement up to and after release and I hope it only gets better from here! May I suggest online multiplayer (even though I love the couch co-op, I would like to mix it up some), some different "slime" enemies you can spawn as a ghost, and maybe an elimination or some other gamemodes?

Literally the only downside to this game is it's lack of an online multiplayer system, though for what it's worth the bots are very human like and responsive as well.Special shout out to the visual style of the game, it's simply fantastic, and the sound effects which make every attack seem to have a special kind of weight to it.8/10, as petty as it sounds I'd bump it up to an easy 9/10 if it had online multiplayer simply because this is the kind of game that goes so well with a crowd of friends to play it with, and many such as myself rarely have the time (or in my case even spare controllers) to get a group together and crowd around a computer screen. Everything else, from the combat to the purchases to the monster evolution system is superb.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								Great game. One of the best games I've ever played. This is an addictive, competitive, dungeon crawler that will keep you on the edge of your seat when fighting friends. Most of the monsters seem balanced and are very fun to use.However...Monsters Problems- The Green Shaman monster thing that summons the zombies need to be nerfed to hell and back. It's very very fast, and has so much health. Not to mention that the slime it leaves behind slows you down so much it's not even a fun challenge. The tentacle things need to have slightly lower health and weak attacks also. The one that is able to go underground and then come back up and attack you is way too ogrepowered. It need to have lower health or do less damage, or not be able to go underground as often. The other one's not as bad, but the tentacles it makes come from the ground are SUPER bulky and take up the whole screen! The minotaur that stems from the rat monster needs to be slower or have a longer recharge on it's sprint. I'm really good with a bow and it frustrates my friends when I kill them because they can't even reach me due to me speeding around the map so often. Other than these specific monsters, I can't really think of anything else in the monster catagory.Boss Problems- Kourok needs to have more health and need to be stronger. Something about Kourok needs to be stronger because anytime someone activates the portal, it's either guarunteed death, (Ghidraak) or a free pass to beat the game. Kourok is nowhere near as strong as Ghidraak and is too easy of a boss. Ghidraak is WAY TOO STRONG! I have probably beaten this boss maybe 3-4 times when fighting it. It is incredibly overpowered in full dragon form, but the fact that EACH INDIVIDUAL HAED GETS THEIR OWN LIFE AFTER DETACHMENT completely breaks the game. You struggle through enough with fighting the boss. Some people are probably saying "That's why the healer is there!", but it doesn't matter! Even if the healer doesn't get hit AT ALL to where he doesn't run away, he only drops 3-4 health orbs at the MOST. It MIGHT be okay for Ghidraak's head to each have a second chanceif their ealth wasn't so high. Their health is the same as if not more that it takes to knock it off of the dragon body in the first place.PLEASE PLEASE POWERHOOF! FIX GHIDRAAK!!!! PLEASE! The ending of the game literallly depends on if the human gets Ghidraak or Kourok, and that's really unbalanced and unfair. It needs to come down to the players skill, and no matter how much skill you have, it's near impossible to kill Ghidraak, even without competant playuers. (I just ten minutes ago fought Ghidraak and was versing an "easy" bot, and lost. I am very good at this game and have played for wuite a while. PLEASE CHANGE GHIDRAAK!)

Early Access Review
								This game is great! The graphics really aren't too bad, and besides, I vastly prefer well-made 2D graphics to fuzzy, badly made 3D graphics any day. Very fun gameplay, and I like the fact that you can, for once play as the traps as well as the monsters. My only real problem with this game is the aiming, and the fact whatever you are shooting goes whichever way you are facing. This makes ranged monsters/heroes feel uncontrollable at times. I would like to see some more content, such as new monsters and equipment, as well as maybe a couple of new traps. I also think the Gatekeeper is a bit easy, and could perhaps have some more health.Apart from that this game is AWESOME! I highly recommend it to anyone who likes dungeon crawl games, as well as Dungeons and Dragons players. By which I mean, of course, PROPER D&D, the Pen and Paper games, not that stupid Neverwinter game made by Perfect World. That game sucks.Anyway, DEFINITELY a reccomendation. They are still bringing out more content for about another year, and after that the price is going up, probably to this games actual worth, about $20. Definitely get it soon!

Posted: May 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								Yeah, I didn't play that game for long, but my reason is that I want to enjoy it with my friends. This is definetly a game you should play with your buddies. It is a dungeon crawler, but the most authentic and unusual one you have ever played. And you know what? It works out really well. The pixelart looks awesome and I really dig the music which fits the artstyle perfectly. Really cool music and presentation and I didn't even get to the gameplay. This dungeoncrawler lets you fight against your friends. Your friends are actually the enemy, not the AI as it usually would be in a coop game. At first, all the players fight against each other and the last one alive gets to "crawl" the dungeon while his friends try killing him as all sorts of mobs. The variation is really surprising, you play a fish, a undead, a samurai and so much more. Those are the opponents of the human player. As soon as one of the dead players kills the human one, he gets to be human. This sounds really weird but it totally works and is probably lots of fun together. I really love that the game finishes so complete. The animations in the menu alone are cool with the music.

Posted: November 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								While on the surface Crawl may not look like much, it only gives you short play sessions and the gameplay is pretty straightforward, it's way too plain.YOU'RE DEAD WRONGCrawl may only have short play sessions and generally simple gameplay, however, the experience that is delivered throughout that short period of time is like no other. You play as the monsters to regain your humanity or fight as a human to keep your humanity. This extremely unique multiplayer experience cannot be overlooked. The only real problem comes in with...limited multiplayer options. Fighting AI controlled bots is more entertaining than you might think however, the serious problem arises with there being only local multiplayer. Although you can play a smooth two-player match with one person on mouse and one on keyboard, online or at least LAN multiplayer would truly make this game much more enjoyable. All in all, the gameplay may be short-lived but it leaves you wanting more, and although multiplayer is still a bit of a problem, it still provides hours of entertainment.Pros:   +Unique gameplay experience   +Outdated yet good looking Graphics   +Endless replay value   +Game is simple enough to be played just with a mouse, allowing for a smooth two-player match (As long as you have a keyboard as well)Cons:   -Multiplayer is limited to local (Quite a drawback) May want to wait until it's finished before purchasing

Posted: November 5, 2014
												This game is a gem of local co-op fun and chaos.I took about 30-40 minutes per game with 2 humans and 1-2 AI players, and the game pacing felt about right. Crawl itself has a crazy simple design, looks and feels like an old arcade game (only 2 buttons, and one stick) I played with a controller and loved it (haven't yet tried the mouse). As simple as it was on paper, playing the hero took some work (monsters actually felt more responsive and intuitive, controllwise, than the hero), aiming ranged weapons took finesse, and missing a special or crucial attack because the target was moving around was heartbreaking, but  each time I moved to deny either my friend or the AI my precious humanity was a moment of absolute triumph. The cutscenes between hero death and the new hero entering the game gave the unfortunate loser a chance to exclaim thier losses, while the winner exclaimed thier victory.The Games basic premise is refreshing, with 4 players all competeing for the chance to be a hero and defeat the boss. The switch off between being the hero, a monster, a trap and a ghost was enjoyable. Best moment was when I realized that the final boss was also controlled by the ghosts, and I took great pleasure in shooting my friend with a simple, but really enjoyable array of attacks. The ghosts will need to work together to take down the hero, because although they outnumber him, most of the time the hero has more health, and often does more damage (depending on monster level), when an AI hero battle began my friend and I would quickly talk strategy and each try to exploit the hero's predicament in order to land the final blow ourselves.The chaotic and quick pace that ensued was enjoyed by all, and even though we didn't win the match, simply playing the game was enjoyable.  Finaly, after finishing the match we got to see the new items we unlocked for our next game, I can't wait to try and find them all.For an early access game feels both polished, and nuanced.8.9/10, can't wait to see what this game becomes!EDIT: With New Bosses, New Monsters and Tons More to Explore I am more excited than ever to keep on exploring the dungeon.. I got goosebumps when I saw the release trailer, and I can honestly say that I expect the next few evenings are going to be spent in the company of friends trying to brutally murder each in CRAWL.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								Crawl is an awesome multiplayer (local) game in which you, your friends and AI will control up to 3 ghosts. The players will be competing for gold and experience while traversing a dungeon. One player will spawn as the hero, and the remaining players will start as ghosts. The currently alive player will move from room to room, coming across pentagrams in most rooms. The ghosts can activate these to summon one of 3 monsters chosen in a kit at the start of the game. Should a ghost deal the killing blow on the player, they spawn as the hero and must continue the dungeon! Each floor has a shop and boss ring the player can interact with, as well as other wishing wells and a few other entitys to work with. The combat is fun, there's plenty of weapons the store offers, plenty of artifacts to modify the character, as well as spells to get from the shop. Pros: A fun (currently local) fighting game for friends to challenge each other in. Plenty of weapons to choose from, a good bit of item variation. Lots of unlocks to encourage replayability. Challenging bosses that force the ghost/players to work together to kill the hero/playerMore content to come! The combat is solid and fun. Nice design for a minimalist/pixel game.Cons: While maps are randomly generated, there isn't any difference in backgrounds or themes at this time of review The sound is very harsh and not appeasing at all.

Posted: April 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								MAN, where do I start. Ok first of if you enjoy classic 8 bit style games or their modern counterparts such as Terraria, Risk Of Rain, Super Meat Boy, Shovel Knight, then I would take good hard look at Crawl.What's so fun about it? For one it has a very fitting, nostalgic, well made soundtrack. You're given many controller options and the controls them selves are very simple and In addition, are very responsive. They don't feel goofy or sloppy. *UNLESS* you choose to use the mouse as your controller, I wouldn't recommend it.The level design is randomized, you will never play a game and feel like you've been on a particular level before, it just doesn't get old. The scenery always seems fresh.The game is stable I've played around 37 hours so far and bugs as well as crashes are rare. It's most likely not a game you're going to be frustrated by because it crashes every 20 minuets.The AI is actually very enjoyable to play with, it's surprising how clever they can be at times which provides a highly entertaining experience. With few bugs to mention besides occasionally getting trapped it's a great addition which allows you to play offline any time.I could go on about the large selection of weapons, unique items, buffs, monsters, mini bosses, bosses, statues, traps. But that would take a long♥♥♥♥♥time.  To keep this short, In the end, for $10 this game is dripping with content, and quality, and fun times.The only thing that I'd warn of, is that the game isn't online multiplayer, only local multiplayer (as in) you plug in 4 controllers to one computer and you can play with 4 friends like a console.Online would be a great addition but it's not currently avalible.

Posted: August 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								I thoroughly enjoy Crawl. The graphics and simple controls give a really nice asthetic feel to the game, like something you'd play on an old console. Despite it's apparent simplicity, Crawl is anything but.The game handles the fast paced action of The Hero (you) being attacked by all of the Spirits (your friends) incredibly well. The team work potential of Spirits to destroy The Hero, using the huge number of combinations of items, monsters, and traps that exist gives the game a lot of replay value.A few parts beautiful graphics, several parts chaotic action, one part slow motion, Crawl is a great game that will (probably) cement your bonds of friendship with friends.Clever trash talk not included.

Posted: June 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Great local multiplayer game. This is NOT a cooperative game as suggested by the "local co-op" tag. It is competitive. Simple gameplay and graphics. Unlockable content for replayability. It's virtually impossible to win at level 10 unless the other players are truly terrible. One of my top picks when I have 3 friends over.

Posted: July 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Crawl is the definition of party games to play when you want to start a fight with your friends. Crawl is a co-op(or single player with bots) retro arcade simulator fantasy dugeon crawler. Aiding yourself with powerups, spells and abilities, and tons of unique weapons, the hero must fight through levels and levels of dungeon against player coltrolled monsters. As you get stronger, so do the monsters. As a human player your goal is to reach level 10 and kill the boss(which is also player controlled). However, everyone else plays the roll of the monsters and traps in the dungeon which constantly evolve and become more and more difficult. If you are killed you become a ghost and your killer becomes the hero. See where this is going? This game has competition and rage written all over it. One can play a quick game within 15-20 min, but the longer the game lasts the more exiting it tends to be. The developers are constantly releasing new content and making the game better and better with each update. For anyone who enjoys dungeon crawlers or simply wants a game to play with their friends, this game is for you.

Posted: September 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								The perfect game to play with friends! A unique take on normal multiplayer dungeon crawlers because 1 player fights as the hero to kill monsters and the boss while the others are ghosts who take control of mosters and bosses to beat the hero whoever kills the hero becomes the hero and the ex hero becomes a ghost. The first person to beat the boss wins, but all players have a combined 3 chances to win against the boss. If the boss wins on the 3rd try the players controlling the boss win and the hero loses. Super addictive and fun. But only has 4 player local multiplayer and no online multiplayer.

Posted: April 23
												Have you ever felt to play an arcade style action packed dungeon "crawl"er? Look no further! The game Crawl is fast paced, action packed, and ultimately a great way to test your friendship. Surely this retro four player game is what feels good for a competitive afternoon of doing nothing and contemplating how to escape the bowels of hell or just being bitter to the point that knowing you won't win... NO ONE WILL WIN. Though it doesn't have online multiplayer the local multiplayer is delightful. I apoligize if I implied you might actually have fun with friends (internet friends don't count by the way). Most of the time no one wins to escape this heliish 8-bit nightmare, but when you do win the ambrosia of victory is quite delectable.

Posted: August 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is just great. Buy it, play it with all your friends, have a grand ol' time. 10/10!More than anything, I hope they add more bosses for 2 player sessions, it makes the game a bit weird when people start buying weapons and equipment specifically for fighting that boss.It would be nice to get a couple more monster paths and deities. Which I'm sure they'll throw in before release. I wish EXP gain, Wrath gain, and gold rewards were reduced by around 25%-50%. (Or at least this was an option in the game settings for a session.)

Posted: March 25, 2015
Early Access Review
 Crawl  delivers just what it promises: A local multiplayer crawler type game with superb art and a great style and feel to it. From what little I have played of it I would definitely recommend it. The game is well balanced, with one player taking on the role of hero, while the other three play as the ghastly dwellers of the dungeon, aiming to defeat the hero for their own benefit and to regain their mundane form. In terms of combat the game flows very well, loot and different weapons can be aquired throughout the dungeon, and can be unlocked as you progress. There are different active abilities that the hero can preform, all from AoE damage to your more typical combat rolls. There are also plenty of different monsters with varied playstyles, tactics and various evolutions for the opposing players to control. The spirits can also possess various traps with different effects throughout the dungeon.As it is only in early access, I can't wait to see this game developed even further in the future with even more content.

Graphical style is cool, infinite replayability, easy to jump into for a quick game, and so many more awesome things about it! The fact that the developers will still be adding more bosses, weapons, and what not, is all the more reason to buy it!

								Great game to play with friends, or by yourself! at first i was worried but the charming pixel graphics, and amazing co-op action made me think otherwise, evolving monsters as an enemy or buying swords and magic as the hero, this game keeps me coming back for more! buy it, you wont be dissapointed!

Posted: May 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								When I saw the trailer for this game, admittedly it made me weak and sent a shiver down my spine. The idea and setting of the game is utterly marvelous. Not only creeping through a dungeon with your friends trying to cause your downfall, but with care, they can take that delicious chance of freedom from you is so very entertaining. I personally love the art style, it's suitable and really helps set the theme for this dark dungeon crawl. The controls are simple, yet very satisfying, every strike with a blade and every dodge to spare your life is as satisfying as any. Not to mention the monsters you encounter, some you love and some you hate, but that makes you fight so much harder just to make sure you do not see your grinning friend shout in success as he steals your humanity. Though many people have complained about an online functionality, I understand however am not too upset by it. If there is not going to be an online function however, I would like to see some improvements to the AI. Often I've found the AI to act in peculiar ways, like they're on a cycle, letting another AI or player get away with things completely at certain times and it's tremendously obvious when they do so. I'd like to see the AI be a little more dynamic and not quite so inclined to help each other, it is a desperate fight for freedom after all. Aside from that however, so far into the Early Access I am loving the game, and hope many more do. Absolutely  worth the price, and the fun to be had.

								Crawl is a chill game for those late nights when you want to sit back, listen to some music, and enjoy one-hand gaming. While it is primarily multiplayer (Players on the same system) the AI for this game is sufficient for an enjoyable experience.Scaling in this game is wonderful with playthroughs ranging from 5 minutes to an hour plus if you just want to max everything out and fight against high difficulty monsters.The final bosses (at the moment being the two) are very easy to garuantee a victory potentially ending the game too early to experience late game content.Controls are fair, plays smoothly and there is no state of (full) debilitation, and the writing is worth turning off anything you have running in the background just to hear.

								What a great experience!Really fun and kinda of adticve. Kinda because I don´t recomend play hard on it, it is more of a Party Play, gather some friends, open some beers, take turns (if more than 4 friends) and have a lot of fun. The main ideia is that a main character fights rooms in dungeons to lvl up to 10, buy itens, and prepare for the boss battle. The other guys tries to kill that main character, either by controlling the enviroment or buy summing slimes and monsters that can be upgrated. They can even control the boss to kill the main one. Whoever kill the main character is revived and this process goes on and on until some you kills the boss, and wins the match. Every match has a different dungeon, and new challenges.Pros: * Really fun * Party play game * Unique Gameplay * Unloackables that extends gameplay * Awesome skills * Awesome Monsters to upgrade and kill the main character Cons: * I dont recomend playing for a looong time with the same guys, because it can get a lit bit repetive and annoying, mostly for the ghosts. * One must love pixels

content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Crawl is- and always will be, in my opinion, one of the best games of all time. So many hidden references and jokes, but yet incripted, et cetera as to stay in the same atmosphere, its mechanics, and gampeplay, and just about everything I can think of about this game is perfect. I mean, to think it is only £7, to think that it is only early access, well, in the future I cant even think on how they can improve the perfect, but Im sure Those 2 creative people down there will find a way, for whatever choice they make, even if they poke fun at a real religion, would be done in such a way nobody would care! The concept of the game is, when you start, everything is glitchy. >:D. Ok, so, it causes a good unsettlement at the start, thats ok. then you start playing with a friend. And then you realise the TRUE PERFECTION THE GAME IS!!!! I mean, I have a friend who owns it, and I am sharing it using the steam library, but I AM SO BUYING THIS GAME ANYWAY! You start as one of you a human, entering a place, and walking around, when there are pentagrams. Your friend, a ghost, goes up to them AND BECOMES A MONSTER AND YOU FIGHT AND THE MONTER KILLS YOU, AND THEN THE MONSTER BECOMES A HUMAN AND YOUR THE GHOST!!! THEN YOU LEVEL UP AND KEEP ON DOING THE SAME THING, AS DIFFERENT MONSTERS, AND THEN YOU GO TO THE NEXT FLOOR AND EVOLVE THEM UNTIL YOU BEAT A BOSS AND WIN! Unfathomably great, atmospheric and suiting music, insrutably satifsying and fun gampeplay, concept, et cetera. All in all, I rate this game: 11/8. Must buy. as soon as I get the money I am going to get another game for my own. Not because I cant play it, but so the develepors get the money they deserve.P.S. when you call yourself something, name yourself HL3. that, on its own, is worth the £7.
