content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is one of my new favorite games on Steam, hands down. Like a normal Dungeon Crawler, you go from room to room fighting off monsters. However in Crawl, the players play as the monsters, all trying to attack the main player. The goal of the game as a monster is to kill the human player and take their place, while the goal of the human is to kill as much as possible and gain XP points. You win the game if you're the player and you go into the boss room and destroy the boss. (The other players also control the boss too!) However, you may only do this at level 10. If the players fail to slay the boss 3 times, the player who fought the third time is removed from the game forever. (And I'm not kidding, it actually deletes your name!)If you have friends locally, this is for you. Just grab a couple of controllers. And no, unlike 70% of steam games with controller support, it DOESN'T need to have XInput. The devs of this game were sure to incorporate as much controllers as possible. As long as it has a USB that you can stick into your computer the controller probably works. Did I mention the game only uses 3 buttons and a d pad? (2 not including the start button) Haven't tested it, but this should work in theory: http://www.amazon.com/Classic-USB-NES-Controller-PC/dp/B002YVD3KMIf you want one of the best local play experiences you'll ever have, buy now. Also the game devs are really active in the community pumping out updates like mad.Positive Features:-Up to 4 Players Locally-Single player mode with AIs-TONS of controller options-Innovative control scene-Active Devs (As of now)-Low Price-High Repeatability-Cabinet mode (You may hook the game up to an arcade machine!)Negative Features:-No online support yet. May not come for a while. Don't buy the game hoping for online support, it's clearly not it's focus, although it may come in the future.Overall, this game is wonderful locally. If you're having a party or just inviting friends over, this is a must have. It's still fun with bots, but not as good with other people, I haven't played much single player but I know it's kind of a mixed response, some like it and some don't. I like it though.Also you can fight Gabe Newell. He hits you with his custom skinned digital knives. 10/10

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								Great game, really polished.  Everything from the animations, to the special fx and sound is just killer.The best part of the game is it brings back the co-op play back into gaming.    Even more impressive is if you don't have any friends, you can enable bots who are very skilled at the game.  Their behavior is pretty impressive.It does take a little bit to get used to the controls and the timing/aiming of attacks.The weapon/enemy power ups already seem pretty robust for an EAG.  I can't wait to see what other cool stuff they add.My first play through with 2 players and no bots took 40 minutes, we were both able to upgrade out creatures to max level and got some pretty sweet weapons.  So there isnt too much content to the game, but the replay value is off the charts.Worked great with my wired xbox 360 controller.

								Rating: 7.5/10What I like:-The game is awesome, it provides hours of fun if your alone and whenever I have friends over we play and we dont stop.-I think that the graphics are very fun and I espically like the art on the all of the monsters.-Being both sides are fun and enjoying to play, and I love how its easy to make a come back-I adore the boss the fights and all the little things you have to micro manage, and the fact that you have to work with the other ghosts to bring down the heros is honestly one of the most fun things What I didn't like:-I think it would be awesome if this game supported online play, but I understand if the developer wasnt going for that.Everything in this game felt smooth and awesome, and if I ever get behind and am the monster for too long I always can get ahead by getting better monsters and then becoming the hero. 								不错的一款游戏呢，特别还是他的新奇地下城风格。轮流的英雄，轮流的怪物，杀死英雄变成英雄，被杀死变成怪物，怪物不断阻止英雄，英雄不断杀死怪物，最后打败大BOOS的英雄胜利！怪物可以进化成更强大的怪物，英雄可以购买更强大的道具。更让喜爱剧情的我是，那次更新在每局开始增加了个小剧情，很兴奋呢，所以呢，挺推荐呢。

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								At the beginning, this game worth to play. It is a game which you can play with your other 3 friends-or bots if you have less friend, offline by using keyboard, mouse and two joysticks. One to be a hero and the other contrl the creeps(read the game instruction). It is not only kill their contrling creeps, but also cooperate with your other creeps which your friend's contrling,  against the hero to slow him go furder and earn the blood to upgrade your creeps, or just kill him-when you think he is suck, too weak in the other word- to be a hero-then you will be the hero. The hero would upgrade- of course -and also can buy the magic, item, weapon and so on to be more stronger. When the hero upgrade to lvl10, the hero can activate the charm to teleport to the final boss room. The boss would be contrled by other players, cooperate to kill the hero. If the boss kills the hero, the game will continue, otherwise, game over, the hero who kills the boss wins. The charm can only activate 3 times, after 3 times, game over also (I forget who will win in this case because no boss alives in our hands). Its really fun to play with your friends, more players, more passionate. Really, really worth to play. Go buy it and play with your girl friend now, and you will break up by my will, ha-ha.CHINESE先说，这游戏值得一玩。这是一个4人游戏，跟朋友一起玩特别嗨，除非你的朋友很少，那你可以跟电脑玩儿。这游戏就是一个人扮演英雄，其他人扮演怪。具体游戏是什么个玩法，自己看游戏介绍。我想说的是，这不只是一个杀怪的游戏，怪之间要懂得配合，把英雄当BOSS打。或者说，你觉得这英雄太菜了，就干掉他（抢人头！），自己当英雄。怪可以靠攻击英雄打出的伤害获得BLOOD来升级，英雄可以击杀怪物获得经验升级，然后获取金币去商店购买物品、魔法、武器等等用来加强自己的东西。10级之后就可以激活符咒开BOSS房打BOSS了，总共有3次挑战BOSS的机会，控制怪的玩家控制BOSS攻击英雄，杀了他之后会损失一次挑战BOSS的机会。谁干掉了BOSS，就谁赢。要是3次全失败，呃，反正我们没有失败过3次我不知道会发生啥事。跟基友们一起玩特别基情，人越多越基情，真心值得一玩。快买买买，然后跟你女朋友玩儿去。然后就会正如我所愿的分手的。哈-哈。

content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								Keep up the good work, really enjoyed this title and it has potential to go places in the local co-op world. If you bring it to online even better!  Traps could use a little work to be more effective (not sure how) and blobs could be beefed up a lil bit to aid in making traps better. My thoughts being if you have to dash in and hammer on a blob mid trap you will take some damage. Also can you posses traps before the monster spawns are cleared? Sometimes I want to throw some spikes around before I become a monster, just a thought. Of course the biggest pull for myself will be level changes, mainly for enviroment sake and more bosses, which i'm sure with time and Support will come to be. Crawl on!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have been excitedly following the evolution of this title for some time now, and at the current rate of progression I am anxious to see this blossom into a super ultra mega ultimate party game.It is totally fun and playable now, but with the introduction of the second boss monster and regular updates with new creatures to fight the hero with, this game will be AWESOME!This game takes a very popular genre, dungeon crawl rpg, and spins it into a unique multiplayer experience by allowing the players not controlling the hero to manipulate the encounters in every room of the dungeon. If you land the killing blow on the hero in the process you then become the hero and now are trying to race to level 10 so you can kill the boss and win the game.7/10 Dungeon Crawl Party Game

								Great for coop! Interesting competitive mechanic where everything changes and you want to be the guy to kill the hero, for a chance to win yourself. And played in single player against bots it's not that bad either. Recommended for it's original gameplay mechanics in a "you get to be the bad guys" style.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is great..But its overpriced.I feel like they really should have made more out of this game. It starts out great.. you trucking along and oh.. whats this portal.. hmm level 10 to use portal gotchya... then you make to level 10.. omg portal takes you to boss ... ok... kill boss... game over... 10 mins... beat the game... wtf i have only played the game for 1.8 hours and i have beat it like 6 times. i get that this is supposed to be more of a couch game and a multiple person game but the bots do a good job. The game play is fun. upgrading weapons is fun. and the currency system feels great. but the game is SOOOOOO short. i was super pumped that the game was level based... then you kind of realize that each level is kind of the same... and it almost seems like they are random generated. so there is no outside... there is no travel or anything like that.  i would have loved to see this in a more open style with armor upgrading aswell.. toss in a minor storyline and some different worlds and more bosses and you have youself a hell of a game. so... overall i would still recommend it... but i feel like 10 dollars is too much... 4 dollars seems more legit for the amount of gameplay you actually get out of it. but still pick it up for the expirence lol

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								For the unacquainted... 'Crawl' is a dungeon crawler with fluid pixel gameplay and mechanics. It, in its current build, it is a 4 player local multiplayer game where the friends you play with are the monsters, bosses and environmental hazards you must overcome. One player plays as the human, whilst the rest of the players take control of the ghosts of comrades that were slain by the human. If a ghost manages to kill the human, that player gains humanity and takes the place of that human. All players must fight amongst each other for this humanity, reach level 10 and kill the boss (of which, each player takes control of a section of the boss). As the human improves, the ghosts/monsters evolve stronger too. This chaotic and entertaining Indie game has brilliant potential, updates and adds new content quite often.If you ever see this game on sale and have at least one local friend also possessing a mouse and a keyboard, I urge you to buy this game and support this games development. It is a game that would be enjoyable to a wide range of individuals regardless.When online eventually comes to Crawl, It instantly becomes a must buy hands down.Give the game a chance. It is constantly improving.A purchase that you will not regret.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								I remember seeing MangaMinx and Boyinaband playing this on Youtube and thinking: "Wow, this actually looks pretty fun!"So, thinking back to that video, I decided to try and find it. Lo and behold, it was on Steam! I immediately bought, noticing it had a single-player feature as well, something that appealed to me, since I don't have the best Internet in the world. After the fast download, I played it for the first time.Wow! I had seen gameplay for this game on Youtube, but I never thought it would be soo much fun! Even against the AI, the game itself has a simple yet challenging playstyle to it that I love, and the music and graphics match so well with the action the game can offer!I have few complaints, to be honest. Normally, I would have a number of them, seeing as this is Early Access, but I only have a few. First, it just seems so short. Eight floors just seems so small for a game. But it is in Early Access, so I could understand why.Secondly, while I enjoyed what I saw so far (I managed to play the AI into losing his Humanity, which was satisfying), maybe adding different kinds of surroundings, like mossy dungeons or dark, dank caves would be possible. It'd be interesting to see how a fight against a mindflayer (or hentai tentacle beast, either way, they're pretty interesting) would go in a cave with floor-to-ceiling rock formations here and there.And lastly, the weapon selection. While the weapons are useful in different situations, it just seems kinda boring to swing a sword or throw some daggers around. Maybe adding a bow or possibly a staff is possible? It'd certainly change how players played the game.All-in-all, this is a great game to play with your friends. Everyone is involved in not just the dungeon-crawling levels, but also the final boss, which was pretty interesting.I've never seen a game like this before, and I'm very much looking forward to seeing how much more is going to go into this game!EDIT:After playing the game a few more times, I realized that it DOES include other weapons, as well as other monster elvolutions. My bad for not playing more of the game and securing my knowledge. All it takes is a completion of the game as either the human or the spirit, and those new unlockables are given to you before heading back to the main menu.EDIT 2:I'm forgetting or overlooking quite a bit in this game, apparently. I recently discovered a spirit-usable statue feature, which allows spirits to become strong, high-level monsters that would normally be available through monster evolution. It's a pretty interesting concept, and one I kind of dread. A low level player can quickly be eradicated by one of these monstrosities, but the battles are tense and hectic. As for other features, I noticed that there are a number of other weapons that are unlocked through continuous play, such as javelins and clubs. Once again, makes play throughs a bit more interesting as time goes on.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								The game certainly has potential, but is far from complete enough to enjoy or PLAY yet. The gods from the start don't really matter, and while upgrading the monsters and stealing the life from your one hapless buddy seems fun, it gets to a point where the monsters, even at max level, become trash against the player. And the frame rate at later levels becomes just as trash. We could barely play. I see a future for it, but for right now, you're going to have to stick out through the bad and wait for some fixes. I want to reiterate- I like the idea alot. I love the idea and baseline concepts. But the execution isnt great right now.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
Early Access Review



YouTube™ Video: Steam Cleaning - Crawl 

			Views: 13		

			(Recorded as part of my Extra-Life 2016 charity stream) Monsters and mayhem await in this asymmetrical dungeon crawl adventure.		

(Recorded as part of my Extra-Life 2016 charity stream)Monsters and mayhem await in this asymmetrical dungeon crawl adventure.  While one player tries to be the hero, the others control an wide array of evolving monsters determined to inhibit their progress, because if they do they get a chance to become the hero.The average round of the game lasts a good deal longer than most adversarial multiplayer game and the action can slow down while players are shopping or debating evolution choices.  Even with a few low points crawl can be a strong choice for a night of multiplayer mayhem.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
Early Access Review



YouTube™ Video: Steam Cleaning - Crawl 

			Views: 13		

			(Recorded as part of my Extra-Life 2016 charity stream) Monsters and mayhem await in this asymmetrical dungeon crawl adventure.		

(Recorded as part of my Extra-Life 2016 charity stream)Monsters and mayhem await in this asymmetrical dungeon crawl adventure.  While one player tries to be the hero, the others control an wide array of evolving monsters determined to inhibit their progress, because if they do they get a chance to become the hero.The average round of the game lasts a good deal longer than most adversarial multiplayer game and the action can slow down while players are shopping or debating evolution choices.  Even with a few low points crawl can be a strong choice for a night of multiplayer mayhem.

content:

Early Access Review
								I read in a review of this game that this game would be nothing but a generic dungeon crawler if not for the co-op elements. What a load of bull that is. This game is gorgeous. The combat mechanics, progression system, attention to detail, and art direction are nothing short of inspiring. Even if this game were just a "generic dungeon crawler" it would be a fantastic one. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								A bunch of thoughts after playing this awesome game:- Don't play against bots. You're losing half the experience.- Nothing is as menacing as a fat fish shimmying towards you.- Remember to chant "Spoooooooky" whenever you're in ghost form. No, it doesn't get old, ever, and don't let the others tell you otherwise.- Amass ghost blobs and deploy jelly monsters to assert your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ status. Best practice includes:** Deploy blob before the player wishes to leave the room or travel down stairs.** Whenever the human player enters the boss chamber, deploy every jelly. Watch them swarm him while the cut-scene plays.- Don't underestimate the small floppy fish and its pew-pew stick projectile. It is the Magicarp of this game. By god, you don't want to die from Splash.- Most monsters let you leave trails of colored fluids. Make sure you produce appropriate sounds during the execution of such skills

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
Early Access Review
Early Access ReviewCrawl almost has a sort of Super Smash Bros feeling to it. Not in the mechanics, art style, or the way the game conceptualizes itself, but in how it affects you and your friends as you duke it out.Truthfully I'm hard-pressed to think of a game that has been as much raw fun as this one with 3 other friends. Crawl is a work of art on the side of game mechanics -  a brilliant concept that has so far been executed extremely well and met my very high expectations.More content is coming to the game, and it drives me nuts waiting for it. I definitely, like most others, feel that the game needs an online component, but the developers have said that they are seriously considering implementing that down the road.If you have a group of friends that you hang out with in person who game, Crawl is an incredible game and one you won't regret getting!

content:
Posted: April 14
 DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review Crawl is a game developed and published by PowerhoofCrawl is an excellent couch co-op game which encourages you to work together as a team to end the hero's life, then take their place and fight your way to salvation by besting the cthulhian horror that resides at the end of it all... or die and have your humanity stolen, only to be cursed to rot forever amidst your wrath in the infinite tombs of CrawlMonsters scale well over time, going from murderous nuisances to outright tough-as-nails murderbeasts whereas hero weapons and abilities are interesting and variedBuffs and debuffs provide an additional strategic layer which raises the game from simply "good" to "great". There's a heavy cyber-lovecraftian theme which elevates the mood. It's immersive and tense, appealing to that intrinsic desire to survive which exists within every humanIt doesn't have online multi-player, but that's a small concession for what is such a tight and cohesive array of elements that come together and create an experience that'll have you sweating from the sheer intensityEven if you don't have enough people nearby who can slum it on your couch to gather up 4 players, Crawl provides a powerful AI that will keep you on your toes RECOMMENDED :)

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14
												You're lucky to have controller support because your fingers will be bleeding after your first game, mine were. This is such a fun game I can't begin to describe it. I got it on sale, but even at £10.99 you're getting so much game for money. It's fun, challenging, a game for the couch, for friends, or just by yourself. The CPU are good at the game, probably better than I am, so it doesn't feel like you're lacking a challenge.I can see myself coming back and playing this game over and over, not for long periods of time, since that's not the type of game it is (however it could be if it was ever given a multiplayer). I can't wait for the next time I get all my friends together, a hot pizza, some cold beers, this game and the couch and I've got my weekend SORTED.Fun game, low cost, win win.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Crawl does what some other games fail at doing. It actually succesfully replicates the old retro feel of games.Sitting down with a couple of friends, and having a good time. The mechanics of this game are great as well. The fac that you can evolve your monsters and hero keeps the game fun and exciting. Also, being given only 3 chances for the play to defeat the boss. It provides an insentive to keep playing through the floors even after you reach level 10 so you can truly defeat the boss. Another cool thing that you don't really see is players being able to controll the boss. This allows for cooperative fun even though it is the final.Overall, this game is fun and I would highly recommend to anyone looking for a retro style game.

content:

Early Access Review
								I had really have high expectations for this game...THEY HAVE BEEN EXCEEDED!This is the *ultimate* couch brawler.  It has simple controls, pacing, and plenty to unlock with each playthrough.  (I daresay, they unlock *too* many items with each playthrough.  I'd rather it dish out one at a time - lest it run out someday!)  Oh, and the polish.  This game is sooo well polished, words cannot explain.  This game *ooozes* style.Believe the hype, and the trailers.  If you don't have real friends, the bots will do a great job entertaining you. This is a capable single player game.  If you do have friends, and don't want them anymore, have the come over and play Crawl.  Just try not to spill any *real* blood.

number of helpful: 109 of 225 people (48%) found this review helpful8 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								A great concept of a game carefully crafted and bundled into an easily set up multiplayer game. There is character progression, adversity which shifts constantly as other players take the role of the hero and the others take the role of the monsters trying to turn him into floor paste and some great bosses which allow for some nice action.Overall, a solid concept. Now the reason for the no recommendation;I played local multiplayer with a bot or two (not having more than one other person immediately available) and the result was a frantic scrabble after the AI, trying to figure out what to do. This itself did not take long, but the frantic scrabble continued on and on and on. Normally, frantic in a game is good, but this just felt like always playing catch-up and never progressing. At the end of each floor, regardless of character advancement, it always felt like we were not quite sure what had been achieved, what happened or what we were even trying to do. We continued on for a while, had a few boss encounters and played as both the monsters and hero a few times each. It was around the time my friend said "I'm bored" that I realized that I was too and had just been forcing fun onto the session.The ghost characters constantly felt like they were dragged from room to room, rather than chasing the hero, often never having the chance to even attempt the various awesome traps in the corridoors between some of the rooms. The blob drops were a nice touch, enabling the ghosts to stay in the action, but not overwhelm the hero too much with mobs. But it still felt a bit bland and it was hard to relate to any of the characters with the constant control switch (mostly with the AI bots getting in there 9 times in 10). Overall, for two of us playing with two bots, it was not fun.Other people with three friends to play with may very well have an awesome time with Crawl, but I think it needs a little more balance, maybe some humor or something, anything to bring it to life. Players need something to work with to get fun out of a game. Other than that, the devs have done an awesome job (love the boss intros, they looked awesome!) and I hope I get chance to have fun with this in the future.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Crawl is an amazing Dungeon crawler type game. One player controls The Hero and the other players play as Ghosts. The Ghosts have to possess traps and become monsters to try and kill The Hero. Whoever lands the final blow to The Hero becomes The Hero. There is also currency in the game, You can get blood by hurting The Hero as a Ghost and you get gold by finding chests. While exploring you can find a blacksmith where you can buy better swords, spells and you can kneel down to an idol that takes all of your blood and makes it gold. That was a basic rundown of Crawl. Before you buy it though, it is only local co-op as of today but the devs said that online is a possibility. I recommend this to everybody who likes a fun multiplayer experience.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								Crawl is a very fun game. It is still in development though, but the devs have done a superb job of keeping in touch with their community and letting them know about what it is they're doing and planning to do. Content is released at an acceptable pace as well. They're a shining example of how these titles should be handled, at the moment. I've enjoyed this game immensely and that's without being able to get people together to play it with me on a regular basis. That's right, I'm having fun playing against the AI. I'm not saying that the AI is in anyway extraordinary, but I just find the game itself so fun that I don't mind playing by myself, even though this game shines the brightest with friends. As of right now I can recommenced this game to anyone looking for a unique game concept and a fun party game.

Early Access Review
								The objective here from the "developers" was to create an arcade cabinet retro experience.The problem is they did an absolutely horrid job of it.  The graphics are worse than arcade games of the era (back then they actually put some effort into the games, unlike these tools).  This game actually looks exactly like someone trying to make a retro looking game and failing horribly - that's the perfect way to describe it.   They captured none of the retro art style. Controls are absolutely shoddy.  Gameplay is terrible.  No graphics tuning.  Repetitive and lacking content.   Complete low effort shovelware.  This game is completely outpaced by the arcade games from 30 years ago that it's insulting with its terrible aping.

Posted: August 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								I really enjoyed what I have seen so far. Although the game only has so much to offer right now, it is early access, and I am exspecting all sorts of new great things during this game's development. The game features 4 player local multiplayer, in which one player plays a normal dungeon crawler. The other three people, though, are the monsters. This is a very interesting twist to dungeon crawlers, and it is well done. I also thought the music was well composed and that the art style was great, but the game is one of those games that without friends, it's charm fades quickly. Over all, what Crawl has to offer so far is great, but if you don't have any friends to play it with, I would wait until news of online multiplayer.

Posted: August 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Highly recommended!I expected this to be a very casual game when looking at the description, boy was I wrong (And loving it!)Crawl gives you a very nice and expansive Roguelike to play around with and it lets you do it with your friends (Competetively!)I was expecting it to be very basic in terms of features but to my pleasant surprise it does have a lot of different weapons and monsters as well as a lot to unlock (At the time of writing this I have not unlocked everything although I have found a number of different types of unlocks)In short : Crawl is a kickass dungeon crawler that offers a lot of depth and an extreme amount of fun when  paired up with a couple of buddies on the couch9/10!

Posted: August 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Never before have I felt that a game truly defined a brawler co-op+VS experience until crawl.Games such as castle crashers and even the old final fights had some sort of co-op and some some sort of vs but traversing the level feltexactly the same as if you were doing it single player with a tinytaste of competitive on the side. Crawl doesn't do this, playing alongsideyour friends means having to keep an eye on every single thing eachof your friends does. Their level, their money, who's hanging back tojump in and steal the kill, who's flinging an all out assault. It'sextremely enthralling and keeps you on your toes throughout eachand every game, you even start to get some of, what I like to call,the mario party aspect. You start resenting and shouting at yourfriends. "WHY DID YOU HAVE TO FIGHT THE BOSS, IT'S OUR LAST TRY!?""DAMMIT I WAS GONNA BUY THAT WEAPON!" etc, etc.Crawl is a great game not only in multiplayer with your friendsbut even in single player, with advanced and clever AI thatseem to know what you'll try before you try it (although theydo get caught on boxes sometimes) making even single playerquests an exciting experience.I've been playing on off since release and even I still haven't unlocked everything which means there is a lot in this game toobtain and because it's still being built even MORE will be added.I hope you consider Crawl as the multiplayer experience of the yearand buy yourself something fun and exciting. With some frogs, demons and just a dash of Lovecraftian horrorCrawl is a great game that deserves your time.

Posted: August 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Get it! Go! Now! Take it! Have it! Love it!Crawl's a short-session action roguelike. It takes thirty minutes or so to play a single round, and win or lose, you'll net new unlocks to change up future crawls. Fast-paced and capable of hammering home a gloriously tooth-grinding need to win, even just against the AI bots, Crawl is exactly what it looked like in that first video that took us all by storm months ago (and if you haven't seen that, watch it at once, it's on this very page).Most impressive is the game's catchup mechanics. Each player has three tracks of monsters that they level up from lowly worms into terrible dragons, from cackling skeletons into...whatever that giant ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ black knight thing is, seriously, he's worryingly huge. The "Vitae" these upgrades require is earned when your -opponents- level up. That's right: The further ahead one player's human shape gets, the nastier the beasts he'll find himself facing, and those who've been struggling will have the most worrying monsters of all. I was a little unclear on how the game decided what tier to spawn you at, but it seems to have a similar catchup mentality (I saw an AI who was wayyy behind the rest of us spawn as a top-tier dragon twice in a row).It does a lot to keep the humanity ball passing around. After reaching level ten (which is not the cap, if there is one), that player, when human, can use one of the portals scattered around the dungeon to take on the boss. If he loses, he's ejected, but gets to stay human (if a human at terrifyingly low life). The game can't drag on forever, though: The third time the boss is engaged (by any player) the portal explodes in a totally metal portal explosion. Defeat of the human player now means the end of the game, a consolation prize for the ghosts and absolute devouring of the foolish human who'd tested his might and failed.It all comes together really well. The joyful rage of getting your killing blows on the human stolen by an UNWORTHY GHOSTLY ALLY who hadn't contributed much is palpable, and the satisfaction at pulling apart the creatures as a human and getting your big, glitzy retro levelup effects is real. Both modes of play are fun, which is probably the key factor here--dying sucks, but hey, on the other hand, now you get to be a giant ♥♥♥♥off black knight and make your friends bleed. And that blood spilled when playing as a monster gets saved up, to be converted into gold when you next find yourself human. There's never a lazy moment: It's constantly important that you be pummeling your friends (or computers).There's an almost infinite amount that could be done with this game. Items could be added forever. Alternate bosses, more sets of monsters to pick from, hideous new traps, diversified level pallettes--the paging space is almost numbing. So buy this game! Encourage our antipodean friends to make more out of it!

Posted: September 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								Can't recomend the game enough. The game is updated every few months providing plenty of time to test out the new additions and get used to the tweaks. The devs are active in the steam forums and are VERY open to discussion and reccomendations. gameplay:one player (chosen at random) controls the hero at the start, the other players are ghosts that control the monsters and traps. dungeons are randomly generated and each room has a minimum pentagram(monster spawn point) equal to the number of players controlling ghosts. each player has 3 monsters based on the god you choose to worship. god can also provide a bonus to your hero character. evolve monsters by damaging or effecting the hero. branching monster evolution tree. While they are fairly limited there is still a large selection and every combination is possible.  definitely more fun with people but single player against AI is fun as well. really the only negative is that when playing with 4 people it is possible for one player to be underleveled in one form or the other. if the other 3 players are the only ones getting a chance at being the hero then the 4th player has higher level monsters but the lowest level hero fighting the higher level monsters. granted they will gain xp for killing the hero (which is usually enough for a 1-4 level up). the player would at this point have a massive stockpile of gold (also gained from harming the hero) and can purchase a large amount of upgrades provided they can find the store on that floor.finding the store isnt dificult because the doors are marked with a red stairs (end of floor) blue portal (boss aka how to win the game) an anvil (shop) or a ? if an area is unexplored.ranged weapons have been fixed from earlier versions where they were clunky but are now much smoother to use. bosses: there are 2 bosses a 3 headed hydra where each player controls a headand a squid monster where one player controls the eye and the other 2 control tentacles. great party game

Early Access Review
								Crawl is an incredibly interesting multiplayer game. Upon taking the role of the human you are thrust into a dungeon filled with traps and monsters all controlled by people you may or may not know and must fight until you win or die trying. Upon death you become one of three ghosts seeking to end the life of a man in order to claim his humanity, during your quest you may choose to work together as you possess monsters and traps but ultimatly you all strive to be the one to deliver the final blow in order to claim a chance at sweet deliverence.TLDR: It's a fun multiplayer game where you all beat the♥♥♥♥♥♥outta eachother. Unlike other multiplayer games with a small player limit , such as a infamous one which may or may not involve italian plumbers having parties, the game balances power based on how much damage you deal, how much the player has leveled up, and ultimatly makes it feel like you always have a chance to take the game. All in all this game is amazing.

Early Access Review
								My first impression of the game while watching the trailer was that the dungeon was filled with monsters that you could take control of as a ghost and the summoning circles were used to summon more powerful monsters. Boy I was wrong. The circles are the only way to summon monsters except for slimes that you can drop as a ghost if you collect enough orbs that float around the screen.I made the mistake of playing the game with three bots my first go. I was lost the entire game as the bots were too fast to keep up with what was going on most of the time leaving me clueless on how to play the game even at the game over screen. I came in third place and only managed to become a human once as the bots constantly got the last hit on the human after I managed to wear him down.The second play through I played with one other person and things started making sense. I finally realized I can summon slime, which I may have been doing before but things were so chaotic I didn't know what was going on.Overall, you should play the game for the first time with 2 players or 1 bot to get the hang of it. While this isn't the best way to play the game, it's easier to learn the ropes.  The more players (once you know what you are doing) the more fun this game becomes.Despite my misconceptions of the game, I still find it enjoyable especially as a party game with friends. Thumbs up!

Posted: February 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Crawl is a fun and unique local multiplayer experience.  In short, it's a king-of-the-hill style dungeon crawler, with players constantly swapping roles as either the plucky hero or one of the three ghosts attempting to take them down.  The way that the ghosts team up against the human is best described as "formalized trolling."The asymmetry of play helps to keep the game fresh, as well as make differences in skill less pivotal in one's ability to enjoy the game.  While the graphics are blocky (unsurprising coming from a two-person team), the animations are superb.

Posted: February 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								Crawl is a game in which a group of 2-4 players are thrown into a dungeon, all of them have the same goal: "Beat a Final Boss to Escape the dungeon". The problem is that only one of those players gets to escape the dungeon by defeating one of the final bosses. At the beginning of a game, one of the players is randomly selected to be the "Human", the final bosses can only be defeated by a human. The other players are then selected to be "Ghosts", the ghosts can posess summoning circles to bring fourth all kinds of controllable monsters to attack the human with, ghosts are also able to spawn controllable slimes, control one of the final bosses parts, and control different traps and statues. When a ghost kills a human, that ghost then immidiatley swaps places with the human, which makes the last human a ghost, and the ghost that landed the killshot on the human becomes a human itself. This game is best played with a group of good friends, trust me, it makes the desperate struggle for victory ALL the more satisfying.

Posted: February 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								The developers are little overly fond of the phrase "torn apart" and variants in their release notes.I mean it's kind of understandable. Everybody gets torn apart in this game. A lot.Oh, you might be wondering, what stops the player in the human flesh bag from just dawdling around and wasting everybody's time? You can do that but when the ghost players aren't otherwise occupied, they're always zooming back and forth gathering up ambient ectoplasm blobs which they can spend to summon slimes. Slimes are pretty pathetic but you can summon them in numbers as a distraction in larger fights and the hero doesn't get rewarded for killing them. Best of all slimes lock the doors when you summon them, which is good fun when the hero is just about to rush out of a trap room.I was surprised though, I was worried being a ghost would feel like wasted time but honestly not only is it fun to be a ghost but you still feel like you're in the running and pushing to win, and as a session progresses humanity starts flipping back and forth between people with hilarious frequencyIdk I'll write a real review later maybe, basically it's good and you should get it. It's wonderfully competitive enough that even when playing against bots you forget that you're playing against bots

Posted: March 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								I received Crawl as a gift from a friend, so when I first started it up, I didn't know what to expect aside from a Dungeon Crawler. What I got was a unique experience, well geared toward multiplayer fun. Assymetric gameplay at its simplest, and yet most refined, up to four players try to get through a dungeon, each trying to be the one to kill the boss at the end. There can only be one dungeoneer at a time though, so while one player slays monsters and evades traps, the others are controlling those monsters and traps. Whichever player is the one to kill the current active dungeoneer becomes the new dungeoneer. The balancing is actually quite effective, though it can be possible to steamroll the opposition if you get a good streak going while active. The game is still under development, so there are only two bosses that I have seen, but I'm looking forward to seeing more from the game.

IF YOU ARE GETTING THIS GAME FOR SINGLEPLAYER and have no intention of playing the multiplayer (which for now is only local), don't bother.

Posted: January 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								1st Impressions: Excellent party game, but stands on it's own as good as single player game.  Very, very fun.  Any criticism I have is in no way a deal-breaker.Pros:- Balance: Lots of attention seems to be paid to keeping it interesting w/ the power dynamic between players constantly shifting.  Getting your minions' butts kicked? You'll rank up monsters faster. Spent a bunch of time running around as the hero killing everyone else? Now you're reincarnated as an toothpick spitting inchworm. All this is done without feeling like it's simply picking on the person in the lead.ADDITIONALLY, the end-game is satisfying regardless of outcome since everyone both worked for and against it the entire time.- Pace: I'm impressed how well it allows for a leveling and item system while still keeping the gogoGOGOGO!GO!GO! mentality.  There always seems to be something for everyone to be doing.- Mood & Atmosphere: The glitched out voice acting brings me right back to scratchy copies of Golden Axe played on poorly tracking TVs.  Pixel graphics can be an aquired taste, but I think it fits well and this game puts a cool spin on it (this kind of "possessed game cartridge").Cons (somewhat minor, but I hope can be addressed as the game develops )- Player confusion: With the unsaturated color palette it can be easy to lose track of your player.  This gets harder during big brawls when some people may be controlling the same type of minion.  Regardless, the learning curve is small.- Advancement & Unlocks: As it stands, the item and "God" unlocks after a session seem arbitrary.  Currently, they seem to be coming out of the glitched-out ether of the game (which is cool mood-wise), but it might be nice to see as least know what's triggering them - Are they indeed random? Tied to playtime? In-game exploration?I've only played this a few hours but it is already well worth the price - for the single player experience, let alone the strong party game this is!

Posted: March 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								I believe this is one of the most solid asymmetric PvP games I've played. At the current moment there isn't a huge amount of content, but the devs do add fairly meaty updates every few weeks. That being said, the mechanics of the game are solid, the way gaining and losing possession of the hero works is an example of good balance mechanisms. It's like a negative feedback loop where the longer you stay as either ghost or hero, the easier it is to kill the hero and be killed respectively.And man does it have style. The music, the ever-present (aesthetic only) glitchiness, it actually makes me feel nostalgic. You can tell what the devs were going for and I think they nailed it. Some people see pixelated art as an excuse for spending less time animating, but the pixel art in this game is made by someone who obviously takes the style seriously, because it actually has a very distinct character and the animations are deceptively smooth for the resolution.

Posted: February 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								Crawl is a game in which a group of 2-4 players are thrown into a dungeon, all of them have the same goal: "Beat a Final Boss to Escape the dungeon". The problem is that only one of those players gets to escape the dungeon by defeating one of the final bosses. At the beginning of a game, one of the players is randomly selected to be the "Human", the final bosses can only be defeated by a human. The other players are then selected to be "Ghosts", the ghosts can posess summoning circles to bring fourth all kinds of controllable monsters to attack the human with, ghosts are also able to spawn controllable slimes, control one of the final bosses parts, and control different traps and statues. When a ghost kills a human, that ghost then immidiatley swaps places with the human, which makes the last human a ghost, and the ghost that landed the killshot on the human becomes a human itself. This game is best played with a group of good friends, trust me, it makes the desperate struggle for victory ALL the more satisfying.

Posted: August 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								I wouldn't normally review an Early Access game but this deserves it because it 'works'. There are no problems with this release from a technical perspective, all that's missing is some content which the devs are / will be adding. What I love about this game is that a 'game'. Almost like a board / card game, the principles and mechanics are the same each time you play but the enjoyment and experience each time (which takes 10-20 minutes) is unique. This is not a co-op game, it's versus; a game in which you and up to three other AI or friends must battle it out to reach level 10 and defeat the boss. Only one player can be 'alive' at one time and the others must kill them by spawning as monsters or using traps to hinder the other's progress. Fantastic little game and I look forward to seeing what other additions are made.

Posted: May 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								I got this as a part of the 'Humble Montly' for May 2016.  I installed and started playing the game without seeing anything about it, and was suprised.  It's a really fun game.  The pace and variety is nice.  You get a fair amount of time playing diety/monsters and dungeoneer.  As you progress down through the dungeon you can buy weapons and spealls and upgrade your monsters.  You end the round by defeating the boss or being beaten as the boss by another player (which is really awesome on either side.  You're either battling a giant monster or get to control the giant monster.)  After you finish a round you start over with a bunch more diety/monsters unlocked.  The graphics and music are retro (pixels,2D) but done very well. 10/10 will crawl again.Edit: One last thought.  Online multiplayer.  This game definitely needs it.  I see it listed as a possibility by the dev.  I really really hope they come through on it.

Posted: February 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								I can't remember if I have ever left a review for any game in all the years I've been on steam.  If I did, it wasn't a good enough one for me to remember.  I'm leaving one now.Simply put:  This game is awesome.  This is one of THOSE games:  Games that I break out in a party setting with my friends and we play it over and over and over.  The idea behind this game is simple enough, but there's enough under the hood to add some depth and variety that it doesn't make the game boring at all or feel repetitive.  Nothing is more satisfying in the world than closing off a room from the hero (as he tries to dash to the portal),  stealing a kill from another monster player (while already at level 10) and race into the adjacent room, open the portal, and attempt to kill the boss.This game will test friendships, no doubt.  It is worth every penny and I can't wait to see what else they add to it.  I'm not crying for lack of on-line multiplayer.  And, the game has some AI in it, so you can even play solo if you want.  (I also really like the 'drop in' / 'drop out' feature A LOT.  Very handy.)  I realize that a lot of people like that component and want it... but the magic here is playing with 3 other friends all in the same room.

Posted: April 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								Crawl is simple but brilliantly executed multiplayer concept. One person plays a hero traversing a dungeon, and the other players play as the dungeon and enemies.  When a monster kills the hero they take his place. The monsters are generally "weaker" than the hero so they need to both work together and compete to get the last hit.The matches are fairly short, usually lasting from 15 to 30 minutes which doesn’t feel like too long. The balancing mechanics are well designed, and players make comebacks regularly keeping the game close - the longer you play as a monster the better off you are if you become the hero, but wait too long and you might lose.The hero and monsters feel good to play, and the players are given several customization options at the beginning of each game allowing them to choose a group of monsters to play as. There are also additional perks which offer variety in play styles.There is a learning curve to the game, and understanding the different resources you have to manage and knowing each monster can be confusing to newer players. The mechanical simplicity helps a lot with this. Crawls biggest problem is that it currently has only local multiplayer and really needs online multiplayer.Crawl is intensely fun and extremely well designed. It is easily one of if not the best local multiplayer games available on steam, and an amazing value for its price. If you can get a group of three or four people together to play I highly recommend it.

								As Jason Voorhees to my top left says: I love it.Seemingly simple, yet comactly complex in this 300 MB Rogue-like Dungeon Crawler as it's been said. I've only gone against AI bots for the moment, but playing four players is utter madness. It's like a timeless childhood game that needed to be around before Gauntlet. That game was still great at the time, but I can imagine the bundles of joy and frustration this game would have, and will have in the near futureFeels great to control your hero and demons alike, the pixelated art-style vaguely reminds me of Hyper Light Drifter, music and sound design are top-notch, and the game itself feels rewarding to play and beat.In short: it's a must buy that can forseeably supply endless enjoyment, and I would give it a solid 9/10 just because the full game is not available at the moment

Early Access Review
								This game is def a treat to play with bots or with other friends in the room.You have a total of 4 players. One player starts off as The HeroThe other 3 players act as Ghosts that are tasked with killing the Hero player so that they, in turn, can become The Hero Themselves.The first person of the 4 players to reach level 10, go through the portal and kill the Final Boss wins!The gameplay is some of the best MP fun to be had, the only big downsides I found was that it's Local-Only Multiplayer..on PC which may break the purchase for a lot of people understandably. Thankfully you can play with Bots who have 3 different difficulties.The other issue I found was a bit of unbalanced gameplay when there are 4 players. There just isn't enough resources gained with the 4 players to max out your monsters or really get powerful with your Hero character some of the time.Here's a review of the game if you'd like to see more!

Posted: December 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								crawl is pretty much one of the few games ive seen that lets you play as the bad guys aside from dungeon land, as soon as i saw the trailer for this game i KNEW i had to have it, in this game there is 1 hero and 1 to 3 other players as the monsters, the hero's main goal is to servive against the other 1 to 3 monsters and try to defeat the final boss at the end and how do you do that? you get gold so you can upgrade yourself and make yourself a fighting machine, the monsters main goal is to try and stop the hero from doing any of his goals by transforming into monsters and despenceing slimes for the hero to fight, and if a monster kills the hero, the monster who killed the hero becomes the hero and try's to do what the previous hero was doing, and as for the killed hero, he becomes a monster and trys's to stop the new hero by doing everything the monsters do, all in all the main goal for the hero is to kill the final boss to win as the hero, and what if your one of the monsters when the hero gets to the final boss, the monsters ARE the final boss controlling all of his different limbs, however thats not to say this game doesnt have down sides like for instants the lack of online multiplayer, yes there is local multi player but it would be so much easier if there was online multiplayer, also it takes WAY to long to unlock any new gods, and gods basicly decides what monsters you can transform into when you are playing as the monsters, but aside from that there is really not much else that deturns me from this game, there are minor things to me like the AI rushing the final boss once they reach lvl 10, but aside from that there isnt much else, id recommend giveing it a shot, thanks for takeing the time to read this and have fun

Posted: August 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								Thought it can be a lonesome crawl with the lack of online multiplayer, "Crawl," even in Early Access form, is a goldmine of local multiplayer value that shouldn't be missed.In Crawl, you and 1-3 other players are all trapped in a dungeon guarded by a gargantuan monster. One of you will be a human fighter while the others are relegated to existing only as insubstantial phantoms. The hero is free to exlplore throughouth the dungeon, delving deeper into its catacombs as necessary to continue on in hopes of treasure, merchants, or a teleporter which can take the hero to the final boss room and either freedom or absolute destruction. As the hero moves from room to room, however, the phantom players can and will do everything they can to kill the hero, from possessing a variety of traps and summoning helper slimes to, most essentially, manifesting in the physical forms of any manner of beast from bear-trap summoning goblins to centaur archers to formidable gazer demons more than capable of slaying would-be-heroes. In the event that any phantom does kill the human opponent, they themselves will procure that player's humanity, spawinging as their own mortal fighter. This is the key pattern of the gameplay, with the hero being rewarded with experiencing points and the chance to purchase rare treasures from merchants nestled within the dungeon catacombs, while the phantoms are rewarded with stronger monsters and blood, which can later be turned into gold should they attain human form. The essential goal is to reach level 10 as the hero and, with the aid of an already impressive variety of unlockable weapons, potions, spells, and other items, reach the teleporter room instanced on each floor of the randomly generated dungeon and face the final boss in combat. The phantoms can possess parts of the boss's body to aid in the assault against the hero in an all-or-nothing battle. With victory, the hero is rewarded with freedom, but, should the hero be slain by his friends in his final assault, his name and likeness will forever be cast into ashes.This game is still a work in progress but is still an easy product to recommend because all of the fundamental features and gameplay mechanics are already quite functional, entertaining, and polished. The core gameplay of killing your friends and becoming stronger in doing so is well-polished and, a few Early Access hiccups aside (including a lack of variety as of the time of this review and a forgivable level of question of balance with certain elements) is absolutely addicting in it's fast-paced flow of action, chance, and reward. The game is themed well with what could be called a haunted-arcade vibe that keeps the visceral action light and helps the player appreciate the charming and beautifully rendered retro-style graphics. While the look could understandably be considered "played-out" to some extent, in the current indie environment, but the atmosphere cast over the room by the up-tempo horror-midi soundtrack is both appropriate and exceptional.With flawless controller support, easy-to-grasp yet hard-to-master brutal combat, quick 20-60 minute gameplay sessions and great mood I would absolutely recommend "Crawl" to any gamer who lives with other gamers or plays often with others in the same room. "Crawl" has no online support whatsoever and, while the bots are functional and helpful if you have less than 4 people, playing alone feels like more of an empty practice session at best. This game is just a blast with friends that you can easily show someone whose never played before a controller and play well into the night without becoming bored, and that's only with the content available as of this very early access build. For 9.99 I personally think that a better value is difficult to find, even here on Steam.

Posted: August 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								 This is probably one of the most fun games I've ever played. Being a fan of both roguelike adventure games and oldschool 8 bit action and never being able to get my fill of either, this game stopped up the hole in my soul. Competitve game fan? This is totally for you. Friendships have almost been ruined. I've made my girlfriend's little brother rage quit several times  (claims Berserk is op, wants you to remove it. plz dont.) The huge amount of unlockables keeps me coming back for more. The variety in weapon animations, awesome/funny monsters (huge fan of the "flash my tentacles from under my robes" mind flayers :D) and interesting spell/item mechanics to keep everything spicy in the dungeon.  I know this is the earliest version of early release, but I have a few polish suggestions for you guys. If you could add twin-stick movement support for game pads that would be awesome. As it is now there are specific advantages that mice have over keyboard/gamepad, and vice versa, namely a full 360 degree aim for  mouse players and  ease of movement for kb/gp. I suppose for some people without game pads it wouldn't be as fair, but I would just as well go out and buy two more so everyone at my pad can enjoy perfect aim and movement.  Another thing, somewhat building off of the last suggestion is within the Kourok boss fight. Along the bottom of the screen to the left is a blind spot where, unless a mouse player is taking control of the eye beam, you cannot hit the challenger whatsoever. Perhaps you could add a scrolling left/right adjustment crosshair instead of the five direction spread for the eye beam? That way every section of the screen can be blasted with the beam.  Besides that as of now, I don't have any complaints. I don't think balance is an issue seeing shops/levels/monster spawns are all random, and everyone has access to the same types of spells/items/weapons/monsters. It's a perfect balance of luck/skill that allows a player to excel if they perform well, but can still be thwarted with a bit of teamwork and quick thinking from the ghosts. I can't wait to see how you guys expand on the dungeon aesthetics, more colors/props/texture and whatnot. If I could give any suggestions/requests on this, I think it would be interesting to see the dungeon floors randomized like the Infinite Layers of the Abyss from Dungeons and Dragons Grayhawk cosmology. Instead of having the floor's identities set in stone, just have the decor and name reflect each other and randomly generated (ie, acid themed floor "The Acrid Hive" or flesh walls/floors "Hall of Goosebumps.") Another roguelike game that has this element somewhat is a bullet hell  called Shoot First. Music reflecting the decor would be awesome too.  And one last request.. please implement a monster that's like the Devil from Heroes of Might and Magic 3 http://www.heroesofmightandmagic.com/heroes3/h3px/archdevil.gifThey are able to enter a burst of flame and teleport across the battle grid... maybe area damage when enter/exit the flames? The scythe would be awesome flavor too. Thanks for reading!~

Posted: October 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Crawl caught me entirely by surprise. The concept, gameplay and art style were all so fresh and unique that I was immediately hooked by this game. There are too few games in the world today that evoke the same emotions as the quest involved in playing a round of Crawl with your friends.Firstly, as an early access game, I was astonished when I picked this up because I found little to no glitches or bugs and it was bursting with content right from the start. The community is also very much alive and the developers are simply phenomenal, always keeping you updated as to their progress and ideas for the game. The gameplay is like nothing I've ever played with up to 4 players playing locally (3 as ghosts and one as a hero) attempting to become a level 10 hero and defeat the dungeons boss. The catch is that since there is only one hero at a time, if you are not playing as the hero, you are one of the 3 ghosts controlling the dungeons minions, traps and bosses attempting to kill the hero and whomever deals the killing blow becomes the next hero.Games are generally fast-paced and frenetic yet the overall game round can take up to 30-40 minutes to play through depending on the players experience levels. The fact that the game is truly semi-cooperative in nature at all times is wonderful and keeps player interaction high. This is what makes local multiplayer gaming so wonderful to me and Crawl really delivers on that front. Many gamers have argued that they wished this game offered online support, and while I understand that not everybody has the opportunity to play with 4 players locally I really don't think this game would deliver the same experience if it were being played with people miles away on the internet instead  of your friends and family on the couch next to you.While I absolutely love this game and how unique and just plain fun it is the one major frustration for me would have to be the fact that the monster who deals the killing blow becomes the next hero and not the monster who dealt the most damage or some other qualifier. This just seems unintuitive, unfair and unrewarding to the non-hero players and I really think this should at least be an alternative option for the game settings if not the standard. I have discussed this with other gamers and while I understand their points as to how making it the player who deals the last blow can work as a balancing mechanism for weaker players I've seen it create just as much imbalance and more importantly change the flow of play to where camping is encouraged for monsters so that they can prepare themselves to deal the killing blow instead of simply attack the hero relentlessly. I truly believe that there should at least be an alternative option available in the settings for the monster who dealt the most damage to become the hero because I find it silly for a game to inherently make one of its mechanics just frustrating for the players  and immediately turn them off the excitement.Despite my one major criticism I have seldom found a game whose development has excited me as much as this one and I really hope that the developers consider my opinions on the game. Overall Crawl is definitely a game worth checking out for any gamer who wants to experience a new and exciting type of game and I highly recommend it if like me you are a huge fan of local multiplayer games that appeal to that childhood sense of playing arcade games and other video games side to side with your friends and family before the lonely Online Gaming era.

Early Access Review
								Despite being a just launched Early Access title, this game is already awesome. It is a local coop dungeon crawler intended for 2 to 4 players and meant to be played with controllers. It's really fun, challenging for all players and somewhat competitive within a group who plays it.A match can last 30 to 90 minutes, it really depends on how it's played. It's incredibly fun and almost endlessly replayable.Though, I must warn you - to get the full fun of this game, you'd wish to have a group of 3-4 people (2 may work out as well, but...) in the same room with at least 2 controllers. Otherwise your experience may vary, because (I didn't try, it's just a presumption) it won't be very fun to play with AI and there's no online coop, so you have to gather up at someone's home. Also it's really poorly played when you try to play with 2 players on the same keyboard.

Posted: August 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								I wouldn't normally review an Early Access game but this deserves it because it 'works'. There are no problems with this release from a technical perspective, all that's missing is some content which the devs are / will be adding. What I love about this game is that a 'game'. Almost like a board / card game, the principles and mechanics are the same each time you play but the enjoyment and experience each time (which takes 10-20 minutes) is unique. This is not a co-op game, it's versus; a game in which you and up to three other AI or friends must battle it out to reach level 10 and defeat the boss. Only one player can be 'alive' at one time and the others must kill them by spawning as monsters or using traps to hinder the other's progress. Fantastic little game and I look forward to seeing what other additions are made.

								This game came out of no where.  I saw the trailer for the first time today and yelled "SHUT UP AND TAKE MY MONEY!!"  Well... they got my money.  Within one hour of gameplay I realized that it was money well spent.  It is a great local co-op party game!  I'm not even sure what to compare it to...It's a dungeon crawl (get it?) but only one person is the hero at a time.  The other people play the monsters.  When they kill the hero, they become the hero who then joins the monsters.  As you level up, you level/upgrade your hero and your monsters at the same time.  You basically play until the game ends one way or another (hero wins or monster wins).  The winner is the person scored the most points along the way.The pixel graphics are beatiful.  The whole feel of the game is nostalgic, yet fresh at the same time.  It only takes a few moments to figure out what is going on.  The polish on this game is already amazing (even in the early access phase).  It's already a complete game in my opinion, but I can't wait to see what content gets added to the full release!  I could totally see different dungeons with different bosses to play.  You get to play as the boss when the hero fights him by the way.Lot's of fun.  Buy this!!

Posted: August 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								Here's a multi-part review discussing how the game works and then information about how my kids of various ages interact with the game.-- How it Works -- The game is gorgeous and we all really love how it looks and sounds. Up to 4 players play locally (2 minimum). 1 person plays as a human, the other 3 play as ghosts. The human is seeking gold and experience. Once the human grows up to experience level 10, they make go into a special realm and fight a final end-boss. If they win against the boss, they are the dungeon survivor.The ghosts, on the other hand fly around grabbing orbs. Once they collect enough orbs they're able to drop simple slime monsters into the map. If ANY monster is in a room, then the doors lock and the human must slay them. In some rooms the ghosts may be able to use Monster Symbols to take control of a larger monster and directly fight against the human. In some rooms, the ghosts can possess traps and trigger them against the human. If a ghost kills the human, they come into the game as the human and the dead player returns as a ghost.Here and there you'll find a shop where you can upgrade your spells, weapons, or passive abilities.The entire purpose of the game is to play as a human long enough to get to level 10, then escape the dungeon by killing the boss.What's really fun, is that you only get 1 chance to fight a boss monster per dungeon floor. If you fail, or are not a high enough level, then you most descend further into the dungeon before you can try again. Between each floor in the dungeon, the players can exchange the power they've gained (granted when the human levels up) to evolve their selections of monsters, to effectively increase the difficulty of the next floor of the dungeon. This is definitely a lot of fun.The final boss is a large beast that 3-players can take control of simultaneously against the human. If the players are on point, it's VERY HARD.With only a few players, this game is very very simple. With 4-players actually trying to do a good job, the game is hectic and REALLY shines.-- Family --My 4-year old is a little unsure of the exact goals. But, she does like possessing items in the maps.  But, she gets tired of the game after 1 run-through.The 9-year old has it all figured out and she does a great job. We really like playing this game 4-player as a family. The 4-year old gets a BIT distracted sometimes. But, overall she's ok. I definitely had to take her through the game a few times 2-player with the explicit purpose of showing her around before she could understand it.-- Overall --I can't wait till they add more boss types and dungeon diversity. This game has fantastic style and I trust these developers to make the right decisions for the game.

Posted: January 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is a very fast-paced, addicting and widely multiplayer mix between a Bullet Hell shooter and an RPG. It's fun to play with your pals in front of one screen and on one couch to enjoy the game.One of the most notable features of Crawl is its extreme replay value. Everybody loves getting rewarded even if they lost, so the game will always intensify after every time you play, which adds more possibilities for a character! The 0.3 update was very useful, because it doesn't take long to unlock everything in v0.2 and especially v0.1. v0.3 added some dieties, evolutions and even an alternate boss that can be very useful and effective. But that's what's best about this game: the frequent updates! But, one of the most well-known features is the awesome animations and the retro feel. The animatons are indescribable. They are the smoothest out of every single pixel-graphic game I've ever seen.Thus, I rate this game an 11/10. That's right. 11/10. Never stop being awesome, Powerhoof!

Posted: January 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is great and keeps getting better with each update. Well worth the $9.99.Pros:-Each time through is different-Good variety of weapons, monsters, traps, and spells-Great fun with a group of friends-Unlocking new items and features after every session makes it hard not to start up another session just to see what the new stuff does-Plays quick (about 30 - 60 minutes) for a session-Very polished already and very few minor bugsCons:-No online support yet: I can't play it with friends who don't live near by : (-Music variety: Good music but there is only a few tracks-Scenery variety: The rooms always uses the same brown brick and tile, a variety of different backgrounds would be nice.Mixed Bag:-Your aim is always in the same direction as your movement. This keeps the game controls from becoming overly complex, but it prevent you from back-peddling while firing a projectile attack.-Fights can become super chaotic, and it becomes very easy to lose track of your character.  Sometimes this adds to the fun and other times it can be a little frustrating.

Posted: May 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Interesting and fun, and well-implemented concept. Consider it to be a combination of games like 'the Duck game' and a 2d roguelike.The game starts off where one player has to kill the other two before anyone can move on. Game over for the other two, right? WRONG. That's what makes this game unique. The other two (in ghost form) can either 'possess' traps or spawn monsters to fight the survivor. You know how you always have to kill monsters to progress in roguelikes? This time, the monsters are your friends.The only thing I'd say it's missing is online mp via steam. It's still a great game, though.

Posted: May 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								At version 0.9 I would say this game is a great buy if you want to play a local multiplayer game that is both cooperative in one aspect and competitive in another. This game is cooperative because you join up with your dead allies and try to kill the current hero, but at the same time you want that last hit to become a hero, so you might not want to pull your weight during some encounters until the right moment arrives. Also, playing against three of your friends as a hero is a pretty big challenge considering how strong some monsters are, so going first  AI on hard mode can be fun to play against since their aim is pretty on point and can make for a great challenge at some times, since I have seem them occassionally stick to walls and just die there. Playing by yourself isn't exactly the most amount of fun and having to unlock new monsters and items can be considered a both positive and negative, since it gives you something to work for, but at the same time it would be nice to have everything to play with your friends from the start. Also, unlocking everything seems like it would take less than 9 hours of gameplay, so unlocking items and monsters is not really a big grind, which helps.I think if they added a few more bosses and balanced a few of the weak monsters, then this game would be 10/10 when playing with friends.Overall,if you got friends and want to have fun killing each other, then this is a game you should buy.
