Posted: January 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Review Written on 25/01/2015 (Subject to change) Scroll for Pro's,Cons and Summary.Do you cherish your relationship with your friends?THEN DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!Crawl was made  with the intentions of turning even the strongest of bonds in to heated rivalries; One moment you will find yourself working with others to lower the heroes health, the next you're viciously scrambling to ensure you are the one who delivers  the final blow to take his place.Crawl offers that which seems to be a rareity in modern games: 4 player local multiplayer. Bringing back the golden days of real couch co-op. The game practically comes gift-wrapped in nostalgia, with its retro-arcade visuals,8-bit audio, two-button combat system and fast-paced gameplay.Gameplay:To begin with, you are greeted with an "Insert coin screen" where you must create a character name consisting of three letters. As simple as it sounds, it immediately welcomes you. Players  must then  select a god to worhsip. Each offering three different monsters with their own evolution path and starting conditions.The premise is simple; One player starts as the hero, who must reach level 10 by descending floors to defeat the boss and claim salvation.  Sounds easy eh? This would be the case, if you didn't have three other players , in ghost form, competing to become the hero in the process, by possessing traps, summoning monsters and deploying slimes. This makes survival as the hero extremely difficult, even more so as the other players gain "Vitae" a currency used to evolve their monsters each time the hero levels up or they draw blood from him.Fear not though! All is not lost, as each floor contains a blacksmith, where the Hero is able to spend gold they have accumilated through killing monsters, to purchase new weapons, trinkets and powers . However, getting to the shop first on each floor is essential if you want to claim all the best gear before anyone else.This is where Crawl really shines, it offers a sense of progression. The amount of purchaseable gear is satisfactory, and even after death, any itmes purchased are not lost.  The monsters don't lose out either, as between floors, players are prompted to evolve their monsters, becoming stronger and increasing their chances of killing the hero.Now, let's discuss one of my favourite aspects of the game: Bosses.Once players have reached level 10, they are able to face a boss, should they choose to do so, by entering the boss room and standing on a glyph. However, you can only have one attempt at the boss per floor, and three overall between everyone. This is when things become interesting, as you need to ensure you are well equipped for the battle, but have to accept the fact that persuing better gear always comes with the risk of dying and not becoming the hero again, allowing others to face the boss. Here's the brilliant part; Once the boss fight begins, any player who is not the hero is able to possess one of the bosses body parts such as the arms and head. Each limb will have a different attack, meaning cooperation and coordination is essential. If the hero prevails, the player wins the game, If the hero is to fail, he will be sent back to the floor with little health and the game continues. If all boss attempts have been used and the hero dies on the final attempt, it's game over. The winner being decided by whoever has accumilated the most XP during the game...Oh and the hero's character is permanently lost, although there seems to be no real penalty for this as there is nothing tying you to your character post-game. You can literally create another character with the same name straight after. To counter this, me and my buddies came up with a system where if your character dies, you can no longer use that three letter name again. Not much of a loss, but better than what the system currently offers.With the completion of each game, win or fail, you earn unlocks. Wether it be new traps, new evolutions for your monsters, weapons , tomes etc.... This adds to the games already enormous amount of replayability. (After 15 hours of play I still haven't unlocked everything!)Mechanics:The game plays best with a controller, although a mouse and keyboard is entirely useable. The two-button system is easy to use; you have a primary and secondary attack and a stick for movement, although the mouse can also used for movement; your character will move to where the cursor is pointed. I found the mouse a little more tedious and difficult to use as opposed to the gamepad. The fighting system is easy to understand, the difficulty comes from avoiding attacks and timing.  Personally, I'd like to be able to carry a ranged and a melee weapon and have another button to switch between the two. All in all, due to the simplicity of the controls, combat feels fluent and tight, with the animations complimenting and completing the system. Multiplayer:Be prepared for cursing, shouting, physical violence and possibly a heart attack-enduced death as you work extremely hard to bring the heroes health down only to have a friend steal the kill and become the hero. This game is best experienced with friends. You can of course play solo, the A.I is more than capable of providing a decent challenge, and is surpringly believeable, making human-like errors. But local couch multiplayer is the heart and soul of this game, and besides, there's no better feeling than defeating your friends and claiming salvation.Unfortunately, at the time of this review, Online multiplayer is not currently implemented. This is a shame because me and my buddies aren't always together, and we'd love to get some Crawl on when this is the case. Fingers crossed though!Another feature I would love to see in this game is Steam Workshop intergration. I'm sure modders would have a blast creating massive amounts of content. This would no doubt increase the lifespan of Crawl.Graphics and audio:Crawl is certainly a pretty game. From the intentional graphical glitches at the main menu, to the colourful displays of attacks ,traps, monsters and blood spills. The pixelated aesthetics feel right at home and sit comfortably amongst the haunting 8-bit track that accompanies them. The randomly generted dungeons  can get a little samey, but there is enough diversity to keep things interesting and the developers have confirmed that dungeon generation, music,  monsters, traps, items and a whole plethora of content will be added. IssuesNaturally, being in early access, Crawl is not without it's flaws; Ghosts being dragged too quickly from the last room into the next when the hero is running through them, sometimes resulting in the inability to utilise a room filled with traps. The occasional door refusing to let you pass or objects disappearing and reappearing. But these are problems that can easily be ironed out; over the 15 hours I've played, I had only encountered a few of these issues and rarely did they hinder the experience.Pro's:-4 playerLocal multiplayer-Progression system/RPG Elements-Brilliant premise; friends play as monsters -Fast-paced gameplay-Lot's of content-Replayiblity-Feels polished-Easy to jump straight in-Gorgeous pixel art-Strong mechanics-Low system requirements-More content to comeCons:-No Steam Workshop-No online Multiplayer-You will put Friendships to the test-Occasional bugsSummary:Crawl feels incredibly well-polished for an early access game, offering fast-paced gameplay, a unique take on the genre and a level of competitiveness that could only be achieved within it's own universe. 8.5/10  "Must Buy"

Posted: August 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								Some people are afraid of what they might find if they try to analyze themselves too much, but you have to CRAWL into your wounds to discover where your fears are. Once the bleeding starts, the cleansing can begin. - Tori AmosThis game is amazing. The amount of pixelated chaos, unlockables, and 3 v 1 beatdowns instantly made me a fan. My only qualm is that the game does not have an online multiplayer feature (yet?), but it more then makes up for it in its ability to immerse you into the adventures of a man against the world (or three friends who want to take his skin).When I first sat down to play the game I expected an early access game to have bugs and technical issues. I have not found one and its made my experience all the more enjoyable. The gameplay is fun and moves at a great pace, the fighting element is rather balanced between heroes and monsters, and the simplicity of the game makes it easy to understandand  and enjoyable for anyone to jump in and play. This game may seem like other dungeon diving games, but despite what the title says this game stands on its own two feet above the competition. Its a casual dungeon beat em up and this game has great potential if or when they decide to add on more to it. If you're looking for a game thats new, but feels like a classic this may be the one. Check out the trailers (which I've watched countless times), read more reviews, and watch gameplay to see if you'd enjoy it. I've been looking for a game I could just sit down, play, and have good fun with. Crawl plopped into my lap like a big fat answer.

Posted: August 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								Ever since I've seen the teasers for this little game, I've been really eagerly waiting for its release. Final verdict is that it was definitely worth the wait, with the only disappointment being no online multiplayer (which hopefully comes). The whole concept is every fun and novel, in which all the maps seem to be procedurally generated as you play. One player starts off as the Hero, while the others play as three Ghosts, which have the ability to possess things throughout the rooms... such as pentagrams, for monster summons, and dormant traps, which can be utilized.The object for the players is simple: Be the first to get up to XP Level 10 so you can open up the portal to face the final boss and fight for your escape. A Hero earns their experience by killing the opposing players who take monster forms, but there's also a second form of specialized experience, particularly useful to the Ghost players: Vitae. Every time a Ghost player causes damage to the current Hero, they earn this currency, which can be used in a variety of ways, like taking a warp to the floor's shop, pay tribute to an idol for quick cash, or... if you're feeling more offensive... use it to upgrade your monsters. That melee skeleton not cutting it for you? Upgrade it to a bow skeleton for heavier, ranged damage. Being an early access game, I can see there's still plenty more to be made for this game, so I can see this system being expanded on quite nicely. Even better, winning the game makes unlocks more things to use in the game, which helps increase the replay value here.My only gripe is the lack of online multiplayer, which could make this game's popularity explode greatly, but even then... If you have four controllers to plug into your PC? Get this... NOW. It's definitely a riot of a local multiplayer party game. :>

Posted: August 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								Thought it can be a lonesome crawl with the lack of online multiplayer, "Crawl," even in Early Access form, is a goldmine of local multiplayer value that shouldn't be missed.In Crawl, you and 1-3 other players are all trapped in a dungeon guarded by a gargantuan monster. One of you will be a human fighter while the others are relegated to existing only as insubstantial phantoms. The hero is free to exlplore throughouth the dungeon, delving deeper into its catacombs as necessary to continue on in hopes of treasure, merchants, or a teleporter which can take the hero to the final boss room and either freedom or absolute destruction. As the hero moves from room to room, however, the phantom players can and will do everything they can to kill the hero, from possessing a variety of traps and summoning helper slimes to, most essentially, manifesting in the physical forms of any manner of beast from bear-trap summoning goblins to centaur archers to formidable gazer demons more than capable of slaying would-be-heroes. In the event that any phantom does kill the human opponent, they themselves will procure that player's humanity, spawinging as their own mortal fighter. This is the key pattern of the gameplay, with the hero being rewarded with experiencing points and the chance to purchase rare treasures from merchants nestled within the dungeon catacombs, while the phantoms are rewarded with stronger monsters and blood, which can later be turned into gold should they attain human form. The essential goal is to reach level 10 as the hero and, with the aid of an already impressive variety of unlockable weapons, potions, spells, and other items, reach the teleporter room instanced on each floor of the randomly generated dungeon and face the final boss in combat. The phantoms can possess parts of the boss's body to aid in the assault against the hero in an all-or-nothing battle. With victory, the hero is rewarded with freedom, but, should the hero be slain by his friends in his final assault, his name and likeness will forever be cast into ashes.This game is still a work in progress but is still an easy product to recommend because all of the fundamental features and gameplay mechanics are already quite functional, entertaining, and polished. The core gameplay of killing your friends and becoming stronger in doing so is well-polished and, a few Early Access hiccups aside (including a lack of variety as of the time of this review and a forgivable level of question of balance with certain elements) is absolutely addicting in it's fast-paced flow of action, chance, and reward. The game is themed well with what could be called a haunted-arcade vibe that keeps the visceral action light and helps the player appreciate the charming and beautifully rendered retro-style graphics. While the look could understandably be considered "played-out" to some extent, in the current indie environment, but the atmosphere cast over the room by the up-tempo horror-midi soundtrack is both appropriate and exceptional.With flawless controller support, easy-to-grasp yet hard-to-master brutal combat, quick 20-60 minute gameplay sessions and great mood I would absolutely recommend "Crawl" to any gamer who lives with other gamers or plays often with others in the same room. "Crawl" has no online support whatsoever and, while the bots are functional and helpful if you have less than 4 people, playing alone feels like more of an empty practice session at best. This game is just a blast with friends that you can easily show someone whose never played before a controller and play well into the night without becoming bored, and that's only with the content available as of this very early access build. For 9.99 I personally think that a better value is difficult to find, even here on Steam.

Posted: August 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								 This is probably one of the most fun games I've ever played. Being a fan of both roguelike adventure games and oldschool 8 bit action and never being able to get my fill of either, this game stopped up the hole in my soul. Competitve game fan? This is totally for you. Friendships have almost been ruined. I've made my girlfriend's little brother rage quit several times  (claims Berserk is op, wants you to remove it. plz dont.) The huge amount of unlockables keeps me coming back for more. The variety in weapon animations, awesome/funny monsters (huge fan of the "flash my tentacles from under my robes" mind flayers :D) and interesting spell/item mechanics to keep everything spicy in the dungeon.  I know this is the earliest version of early release, but I have a few polish suggestions for you guys. If you could add twin-stick movement support for game pads that would be awesome. As it is now there are specific advantages that mice have over keyboard/gamepad, and vice versa, namely a full 360 degree aim for  mouse players and  ease of movement for kb/gp. I suppose for some people without game pads it wouldn't be as fair, but I would just as well go out and buy two more so everyone at my pad can enjoy perfect aim and movement.  Another thing, somewhat building off of the last suggestion is within the Kourok boss fight. Along the bottom of the screen to the left is a blind spot where, unless a mouse player is taking control of the eye beam, you cannot hit the challenger whatsoever. Perhaps you could add a scrolling left/right adjustment crosshair instead of the five direction spread for the eye beam? That way every section of the screen can be blasted with the beam.  Besides that as of now, I don't have any complaints. I don't think balance is an issue seeing shops/levels/monster spawns are all random, and everyone has access to the same types of spells/items/weapons/monsters. It's a perfect balance of luck/skill that allows a player to excel if they perform well, but can still be thwarted with a bit of teamwork and quick thinking from the ghosts. I can't wait to see how you guys expand on the dungeon aesthetics, more colors/props/texture and whatnot. If I could give any suggestions/requests on this, I think it would be interesting to see the dungeon floors randomized like the Infinite Layers of the Abyss from Dungeons and Dragons Grayhawk cosmology. Instead of having the floor's identities set in stone, just have the decor and name reflect each other and randomly generated (ie, acid themed floor "The Acrid Hive" or flesh walls/floors "Hall of Goosebumps.") Another roguelike game that has this element somewhat is a bullet hell  called Shoot First. Music reflecting the decor would be awesome too.  And one last request.. please implement a monster that's like the Devil from Heroes of Might and Magic 3 http://www.heroesofmightandmagic.com/heroes3/h3px/archdevil.gifThey are able to enter a burst of flame and teleport across the battle grid... maybe area damage when enter/exit the flames? The scythe would be awesome flavor too. Thanks for reading!~

Posted: January 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								Awesome couch multiplayer game. Great music and visual imo. Gameplay is in a top down dungeaon crawling game. Main advantage it has is that it is very different compared to other couch multiplayer games. One person is the "hero" whilst others are ghosts going down levels of a dungeon. HeroThe aim of the hero is to level up to level 10, activate the portal and defeat the boss monster. The hero can also buy stuff from the black smith and store including weapons, buffs and special ability items. GhostsThe aim of the ghosts is to kill the hero and therefroe become the new hero. They do this by possessing traps and activating pentagrams to become monsters in the dungeon. The ghosts get viae points by other heroes leveling up to spend on evolving their monsters. Their is a good variety of monsters as of v0.3 with more to come. When the monsters hurt the hero they earn blood which they convert to gold to buy stuff when they are the hero.BossOnce a hero reaches level 10 they can activate a portal on a dungeon floor, with each floor's portal only allowed to be activated once, to fight the boss. The boss is controlled by the ghost players, eg one boss hass two tentacles and a head  making three control points and one boss has three different heads. If the hero dies they are shunted out. The boss can be fought three times total in a match until the games end.NO signs of online multiplayer anytime soon but I don't mind as the game has decent AI and I prefer them spend time adding more environements, creatures and bosses.In the end I would recommend this game if you want a multiplayer game such as towerfall, samurai gun, gang beasts etc mixed with dungeon crawling rouguelike gameplay and assymetric multiplayer like evolve or nintendo land games.

Posted: November 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								Whether you're looking for a rogue-like dungeon crawl to play with family/freinds locally or by yourself, this is definitely a game you wouldn't want to skip over. This game has simplistic but very fun gameplay, mixed together with a very, very interesting twist of constantly playing back and forth as a human or monsters/traps as you perish within the duengeon.The gameplay is quick, choatic, and can be quite thrilling! You'll be screaming at your undead friends when they kill you, or they somehow manage to get the kill on the human before you. You'll have a laugh or two when a crate is randomly thrown at the alive player in a completely quite room. You also will curse the slimes your friends constantly spawn over and over, one at a time, in a single room to keep you trapped in there for a short while.There are countless different monsters with very different attack moves, which can change over the course of the game through upgrades. The same can be said about the weapons, items, and abilities for the human player, as there are numerous weapons with random bonuses, stat leveling (through drinking potions), trinkets that effect gameplay, and abilities for them to purchase as well. There are various monster sets to choose from, that come along with a deity that will grant the players bonus effects through out their game.Overall, it's a fantastic game with very few issues. Mainly, the only issue I have is that it can be insanely difficult, if not near impossible, to defeat the boss(es) if they are played by skilled players. Of course, that is only an issue with the people I play with, and not the game itself, but never-the-less, be prepared to have a very, very challenging fight if you play this game with other skilled players.

Posted: November 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is great to play with friends and has enough to it to play on your own. Losing our character when you fail the last attempt at a boss adds a nice little thing for veterans.

Posted: November 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game revolutionizes 1v3 asymetrical gameplay by relying on an old game genre and reimagining it as a multiplayer experience. Basically, this game uses the dungeon crawler formula to pit one human or "hero" against 3 vengeful spirits. These teams are, however, not static. Ghosts can become monsters and control traps to attempt to defeat the human and steal his body for themselves.At it's core, this is  not a dungeon crawler or an asymmetrical team game, but a cut-throat free for all game (often only really seen in boardgames or table-top games) where you must work together with your fellow players whilst plotting how you want to take them down at the same time. Thus, the race to salvation begins.You need to reach lvl 10.You need to defeat the boss.You need to survive the pit.But how can you defeat the hero without working together?But are you able to defeat the boss with just the stats/equipment you have now?But why are there no female hero sprites??? #triggered #ermahgerd #triggered

								Literally my favorite Steam game. It is visually stunning, an artisic masterpiece, and its simple intuitive controls make the game feel so polished and solid. Posted: March 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								PROS:The easiest way I can describe it is that it's concept reminds me of The Legend of Zelda but only if one character plays as Link where you're a little guy with a sword and the other plays as Ganon where you summon monsters of all kind after the little guy with the sword. It's a really fun concept and I can see Powerhoof is trying to take as much advantage of this as they can, which of coarse is FREAKING AWESOME! I like how you don't even need to power up all the eldritch stones to activate the portal to the boss and how it's a different monster with it's own unique mechanics depending on how many you have powered up.This game is also a good example of how a video game doesn't need a real story what so ever to be enjoyable because it could leave your imagination up to do that if you wanted to like how it does for a silent protagonist's personality or motives. You can imagine the human as a hero and the ghost(s) as the villain, or the human as the villain or the ghost(s) as the hero(s), or there could be no good guy here at all but instead just poor souls fighting over a change at freedom and riches like a bunch of hungry wolves fighting over a dead rabbit. The possibilities are endless to what it could be happening down in the caverns.CONS:As fun as the game is and as much as I hate to admit it, the only thing that could make it complete is if they do put together a little online feature where you can play with friends from all over. Sure it's got local co-op AND I know that it's still on there to do list, but my point still stands that online is the only thing that's missing. But even with online still yet to be a reality, the game is pretty solid even when playing by yourself. Though when I played it by myself, I couldn't help but notice there's some slight kinks in the ghosts' AI. But it's still early access and these kinks do seem pretty minor like sometimes the ghosts would stay stuck in a corner for some reason, interracting with a trap that you're no where near which only happened once for me and they stopped obviously as soon as I left the room.ALL IN ALL:Really solid game, enjoyable even when playing by yourself, still waiting on that online even after a year and a bit but they can take there times since I'm sure they're getting to that soon.

Posted: January 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								Crawl is a retro 8 bit pixel throwback with quite a gameplay twist. The controls on gamepads are very simple, being the traditional A=attack and B=special, like a true child of the '80s. The gameplay is superb, though a bit tricky to get used to at first. (But hey, they're doing something new, so it will take a little bit of getting used to).The ability of the player mobs to spawn on pentagrams is well thought out, but they also have the ability to take control of traps to further inhibit the Dungeoneer. This can become a bit of a cluster♥♥♥♥ if you have 3 enemy players, as some of the rooms are very small in regards to the amount of anti-hero objects in them.The leveling up features seem pretty smooth, as well as the Wrath mechanics, and the shop. The Boss pentagram that appears on each level (accessible at lvl 10) sends you to a room where you battle one of many huge bosses. This can feel a bit like an attack-spam sometimes, but only if you are significantly prepared for the boss through the purchase of upgrades. It does still feel like a retro boss battle.Overall I would give Crawl an 8/10They are bringing something new and interesting to the table in the form of something familiar. It is a great game to play  alone, or with friends, and it's a great excuse to cuss your friends out when they booby trap kill you before the final room.

Posted: August 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								Here's a multi-part review discussing how the game works and then information about how my kids of various ages interact with the game.-- How it Works -- The game is gorgeous and we all really love how it looks and sounds. Up to 4 players play locally (2 minimum). 1 person plays as a human, the other 3 play as ghosts. The human is seeking gold and experience. Once the human grows up to experience level 10, they make go into a special realm and fight a final end-boss. If they win against the boss, they are the dungeon survivor.The ghosts, on the other hand fly around grabbing orbs. Once they collect enough orbs they're able to drop simple slime monsters into the map. If ANY monster is in a room, then the doors lock and the human must slay them. In some rooms the ghosts may be able to use Monster Symbols to take control of a larger monster and directly fight against the human. In some rooms, the ghosts can possess traps and trigger them against the human. If a ghost kills the human, they come into the game as the human and the dead player returns as a ghost.Here and there you'll find a shop where you can upgrade your spells, weapons, or passive abilities.The entire purpose of the game is to play as a human long enough to get to level 10, then escape the dungeon by killing the boss.What's really fun, is that you only get 1 chance to fight a boss monster per dungeon floor. If you fail, or are not a high enough level, then you most descend further into the dungeon before you can try again. Between each floor in the dungeon, the players can exchange the power they've gained (granted when the human levels up) to evolve their selections of monsters, to effectively increase the difficulty of the next floor of the dungeon. This is definitely a lot of fun.The final boss is a large beast that 3-players can take control of simultaneously against the human. If the players are on point, it's VERY HARD.With only a few players, this game is very very simple. With 4-players actually trying to do a good job, the game is hectic and REALLY shines.-- Family --My 4-year old is a little unsure of the exact goals. But, she does like possessing items in the maps.  But, she gets tired of the game after 1 run-through.The 9-year old has it all figured out and she does a great job. We really like playing this game 4-player as a family. The 4-year old gets a BIT distracted sometimes. But, overall she's ok. I definitely had to take her through the game a few times 2-player with the explicit purpose of showing her around before she could understand it.-- Overall --I can't wait till they add more boss types and dungeon diversity. This game has fantastic style and I trust these developers to make the right decisions for the game.

The game itself has you battling to be the hero to kill the boss, you become the hero by killing the current hero with one of your possessed/summoned monsters or a possessed trap, this as you are a ghost. Posted: January 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								What an incredibly well done couch/party game!Pretty quick, entertaining runs; easy to learn, (moderately) hard to master; weird ideas; very different monsters, traps and items; excellent retro style.The game might not seem fair every moment, because sometimes the hero gets bashed without a chance or monsters squished like bugs, but fairness comes back by the game's leveling system: the more the enemy heros level up, the more you can improve your monsters. That way even players with bad luck or lower skills advance.Even in Early Access Crawl already is more enjoyable and has a higher replay value than many (if not most!) finished games. One of the few things that should be improved (especially concerning balance) are the boss fights, but even if the game stayed exactly as it is, I'd still love it. (In fact, I wonder how much better it can possibly get...)

Posted: January 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is an example of Early Access working, it is extremely replayable and feels more complete than most games at launch as is. I have been playing this 2 player couch coop with no Bots and it is an absolute blast, the combat for the hero is fluid and responsive with  the the upgrades from the shop and frequent gold snowball into making you feel massive progression even though each game is pretty quick.Early game for us the monster player felt a bit too weak if they do not have AI to support (AI is very dull - some ways incredible other absolutely stupid) and initial monster choices are very poor so you just have to grind them down with traps and attrition unless you have a flying eyeball - all hail the flying eyeball!The game does a great job of sorting itself out by linking player progress to your monster evolution and becomes a pretty tense duel around the mid game, (or more reason to disrupt your coop partner irl) so maybe it will be optimised around 4 player but dont let that stop you if you have no interest in bots and often play with less people. The biggest critisisms of course is the current monster balancing and few unique path choices on their growth, this is what makes a game meaningful and replayable, its not quite there yet but this is where its going to grow I imagine. Online multiplayer and a console release would make this instant indie GOTY and print money, as it is an absolutely incredible game that everyone should buy!

Posted: November 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								One of the best local multiplayer games I have ever played, perhaps the best if I exclude tekken nostalgia. The core idea of this game is just THAT good. And it is executed brilliantly. Easy to pick up and play, it thrusts up to four players into a dungeon full of traps and doors to the unknown. One player is always the human, trying to stay alive and gain levels by fighting monsters. The monsters, however, are controlled by your "friends" - many rooms have pentagrams on the floor, which, when approached by a ghost player, allow the summoning of a ghastly creature from the depths. As the player character gains strength, the monster players gain "wrath" - which in turn allows them to upgrade their monsters to a new, unique form. This way, the 1-3 players that are not currently the human constantly gain strength, which usually means it's just a matter of time until the human falls...And when he does, the "ghost" that struck the final blow trades places with the human, and gains XP and gold in his stead. The goal is to reach level 10 and challenge the boss of the dungeon. If you beat him, you win. If you lose, there are 2 more tries ANY player has to get out. Else, everyone loses. After a game you unlock more items to buy, more dungeon objects to encounter and use (at your own risk..) and more deities. At the beginning of each game, each player picks a deity, which will 1) determine what base monsters / upgrade paths are available to that player and 2) what passive ability / starting item the human form of that player has. There is a lot more diversity to this game than initially meets the eye, which is great. Dungeons are also procedually genereated, the intro varies a lot- it really tries hard not to get old anytime soon.And on that it succeeds in my opinion. If you have any opportunity to get friends in on this - do it. You wont regret it. There are simple yet interesting combat mechanics to master, and every game unfolds differently, depending on deities and what the shop has to offer on each stage. It's really good. As for the early access, it's hardly noticable - I actually only remebered because of the frequent updates.

Posted: November 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								Crawl has become, unexpectedly, one of my favorite games Mycobacterium smegmatis mc2155. As an indie game, it will be money well spent (privded you have people to play with for some fantastic couch co-op). Get it, its great.I own a lot of shared/split-screen games. I tend to organize a bunch of team sports, and pre-drinking is mandatory. To this end, having simple to play, local co-op games is a must for some good rowdy entertainemt. Crawl is simple to play (moderately hard to master). There are only two buttons, attack and special but the hook is that it is dynamic 3v1 set up. A 'human' player competes against three 'ghosts' to gain enough levels to be the one that challenges the boss. Ghosts inhabit monsters to kill the 'human'. The one that lands the deadly blow becomes 'human'. As 'human' players level, ghosts get currency to in turn level up their mosters. Thus, if you can't get a kill on a human and everyone levels around you, you will have more to spen on leveling monsters, ergo a higher chance of getting the kill. As monsters do damage to humans they gain currency they can use if they become human in a shop to increase their effectiveness. Once someone reaches enough power to challenge a boss, the 3 ghots comibine to controll that boss to fight. Overall, the game design is solid, unique, and super fun. If there are no monsters to inhabit, ghost characters can controll various traps and jump into items to harrass the 'human'.I've had this game for a long time and the developers are still providing updates with more monster evolutions, more items to purchas in the shop, and more trap dynamics. The only even remotely (possibly)negative thing is they have yet to add to the roster of end game bosses (currently there are only 2).While the overall this is a simple game there is a slight learning curve (mainly what are the monster attack/specials, possible human specials). There is progression (unlocking monster evolves/items), but it is pretty quick. Super casual players may be turned off by this, but overall, whenever I bust this game out, response is always positive.

Posted: August 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								good gameNo but srsly in the recent years of degrading game depth/skill ceiling, increasing focus on pretty graphics and simply catering to the average person, this game is what you and your group of competitive gaming oldones need. It's easy to pick up, since its basically only two action buttons, but the sheer amount of movement, item and monster mechanics allow it to be played in uncountable ways. To cut to the point: This piece of software right here is pretty much a top-down twin-stick rpg/shooter versus/co-op game, currently only supporting local multiplayer. Controls are basically L-stick to move/aim, A to shoot/slash, B to dodge/special move.The goal for every player is the same, kill the boss after reaching lvl10 in human form, to be released from the dungeon. A sudden-death at the start determines the first ''runner'' to enter the dungeon in human form, your slaughtered companions souls steadily haunting your every step to kill you and take away your humanity for themselves i.e. their try at defeating the dungeon. The dungeon in itself is harmless, but every trap and contraption can be used by the ghosts of the other players to make your run a living bullethell. Furthermore each room contains a differing amount of pentagrams which can be used as a ghost to spawn into a monster, each with its own unique moveset. These creeps can be lvled after every floor, levels in human form of enemy player determine your evolution points. Human Form spends picked up cash to get new weapons, artifacts, moves etc. each weapon with its own moveset, each ability with its own uses. After a human form hits lvl 10 they can enter the boss portal on every floor to have one of the three tries at defeating the boss, problem is, the boss is also controlled by the enemy players, making this whole game a really competitive experience best enjoyed if all players have the gitgud mentality.Soundtrack is amazing, fits the game perfect, really raw dark 8bit sounds whose rhythm still keeps you looped into the game.Graphics can be seen on screens.Only missing feature is online-multiplayer, in other aspects this is a game I support in every way and would buy again just to support development and show my gratitude for creating this piece of art. Definitely worth more than 10bucks.p.s. gitgud, dodge moves only, abuse the MoI, take the bow, crush the boss

								I cannot even begin to explain how amazing this game is. I bought it yesterday because the idea of the game seemed amazingly interesting! (It's amazing!) and it truly is super interesting. Posted: September 11, 2016
Early Access Review
This game brought me back to gaming outside of LoL.This game breaths life into the dungeon crawler genre with its smooth controls and original playstyle. There are only a couple monsters that feel remotly similar, but other than those few every monster is unique in its playstyle and every move you make counts. It's fast paced and as fun as advertised. What sold me for this game before purchase was the monolouge, and the actual game has no shortage of pre battle monolouges with that amazingly ghastly voices. I legitimatly get shivers on some of them. Every game that you start has a completely new monolouge that you have most likely not heard in any of your previous games.The combat is very fair and you know what you did wrong if you die. The mosters have very cut and dry strengths and weaknesses. Though some of them require that you have a certain type of weapon to counter, or you're good at using special spells.Very original and very fun. Worth every cent even in single player mode and once multiplayer comes out it is worth even more!

Posted: September 11, 2016
Early Access Review
This game brought me back to gaming outside of LoL.This game breaths life into the dungeon crawler genre with its smooth controls and original playstyle. There are only a couple monsters that feel remotly similar, but other than those few every monster is unique in its playstyle and every move you make counts. It's fast paced and as fun as advertised. What sold me for this game before purchase was the monolouge, and the actual game has no shortage of pre battle monolouges with that amazingly ghastly voices. I legitimatly get shivers on some of them. Every game that you start has a completely new monolouge that you have most likely not heard in any of your previous games.The combat is very fair and you know what you did wrong if you die. The mosters have very cut and dry strengths and weaknesses. Though some of them require that you have a certain type of weapon to counter, or you're good at using special spells.Very original and very fun. Worth every cent even in single player mode and once multiplayer comes out it is worth even more!

								I cannot even begin to explain how amazing this game is. I bought it yesterday because the idea of the game seemed amazingly interesting! (It's amazing!) and it truly is super interesting. The amount of detail and creativity put into this game blows my mind. Just the concept alone is cool. Then you unlock things as you play and there are new bosses and so much more. It adds a whole nother level of greatness. My only complaint is if you play this game with 4 players then only three tries are given (total or between all characters) to fight the boss. This makes it more grindy due to the fact that everyone else is controlling the boss and it's a 3v1. I love the challenge but maybe there could be an option for how many tries you get so it doesn't get so grindy. Anyways I love the game. It's fantastic and I recommend it to everyone. Amazing job on this game and thank you for making this game. Defiantly a favorite forever

Posted: September 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								Crawl is a single or up to four player local co-op game. The retro style and the pixel art is flawless. This games concept is interesting and well executed. You can play as the monsters or the hero. Who ever lands the final blow on the hero becomes the hero. If one player is really good at the hero the other player will have leveled up their monster meaning they can take over. Another great point is that when it comes to the boss fight the other three players get to each control a part of the boss while the fourth player tries to beat the game. The different upgrade paths in the monsters keeps the game diverse and intersenting.Cons: one thing this game is missing is online co-opThis game is looking up to become a well polished multiplayer game. This game is great with friends and is a fun quick burst of gameplay.

Posted: February 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								The developers are little overly fond of the phrase "torn apart" and variants in their release notes.I mean it's kind of understandable. Everybody gets torn apart in this game. A lot.Oh, you might be wondering, what stops the player in the human flesh bag from just dawdling around and wasting everybody's time? You can do that but when the ghost players aren't otherwise occupied, they're always zooming back and forth gathering up ambient ectoplasm blobs which they can spend to summon slimes. Slimes are pretty pathetic but you can summon them in numbers as a distraction in larger fights and the hero doesn't get rewarded for killing them. Best of all slimes lock the doors when you summon them, which is good fun when the hero is just about to rush out of a trap room.I was surprised though, I was worried being a ghost would feel like wasted time but honestly not only is it fun to be a ghost but you still feel like you're in the running and pushing to win, and as a session progresses humanity starts flipping back and forth between people with hilarious frequencyIdk I'll write a real review later maybe, basically it's good and you should get it. It's wonderfully competitive enough that even when playing against bots you forget that you're playing against bots

Posted: February 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								I can't remember if I have ever left a review for any game in all the years I've been on steam.  If I did, it wasn't a good enough one for me to remember.  I'm leaving one now.Simply put:  This game is awesome.  This is one of THOSE games:  Games that I break out in a party setting with my friends and we play it over and over and over.  The idea behind this game is simple enough, but there's enough under the hood to add some depth and variety that it doesn't make the game boring at all or feel repetitive.  Nothing is more satisfying in the world than closing off a room from the hero (as he tries to dash to the portal),  stealing a kill from another monster player (while already at level 10) and race into the adjacent room, open the portal, and attempt to kill the boss.This game will test friendships, no doubt.  It is worth every penny and I can't wait to see what else they add to it.  I'm not crying for lack of on-line multiplayer.  And, the game has some AI in it, so you can even play solo if you want.  (I also really like the 'drop in' / 'drop out' feature A LOT.  Very handy.)  I realize that a lot of people like that component and want it... but the magic here is playing with 3 other friends all in the same room.

Posted: April 2
Early Access Review
								I have had this game for quite a while now, basically  the moment I saw it I bought it  and it has  Not  been a disappointment! Although I think this game is really awesome I sure hope there are a few things I hope they add to the game either with the release or I hope they continue to develope it afterwards.A list of my concerns:  The current game has only 2 bosses, from what I've seen with the full release on 04/11/17 that there should be at least one more, I hope there is more than 3 bosses it would be nice to have around 10 for a vast diversity and challange. Some of the elements in the game are not really used all that much, especially the ice element, which there is an item that helps a human character when they are afflicted by this element. To my knowledge there are only two ways to inflict an icy affect on a human character and that is with one of the more advanced monsters and with one of the two current bosses. A huge concern is that they are going to keep the same floor pattern as they have now. What I mean by this is that everytime you advanced through the dungeon onto another floor, its just another randomly generated floor. It would be nice to have themed floors, like an icy floor zone, or acid, spikes, fire, death, blood, etc. the list could go on.  This game very well could end up feeling like an unfinished game if some care isn't considered and implemented. It almost feels that the developers are tired of working on this project and just want to release it and move onto the next project. I may be wrong about this, but either way it will still be an amazing game!     I don't know what they will all be adding to the game when it is finally out of early acces, but I sure hope the developers don't stop developing this game besides the occasional hotfix or small update since it really needs so much more. It would be sad if they leave this game a little lack luster when it could be an all time classic and an absolute amazing adventure that I want to cherish for many more years to come with my friends and family.

Posted: January 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								What an incredibly well done couch/party game!Pretty quick, entertaining runs; easy to learn, (moderately) hard to master; weird ideas; very different monsters, traps and items; excellent retro style.The game might not seem fair every moment, because sometimes the hero gets bashed without a chance or monsters squished like bugs, but fairness comes back by the game's leveling system: the more the enemy heros level up, the more you can improve your monsters. That way even players with bad luck or lower skills advance.Even in Early Access Crawl already is more enjoyable and has a higher replay value than many (if not most!) finished games. One of the few things that should be improved (especially concerning balance) are the boss fights, but even if the game stayed exactly as it is, I'd still love it. (In fact, I wonder how much better it can possibly get...)

Posted: January 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is an example of Early Access working, it is extremely replayable and feels more complete than most games at launch as is. I have been playing this 2 player couch coop with no Bots and it is an absolute blast, the combat for the hero is fluid and responsive with  the the upgrades from the shop and frequent gold snowball into making you feel massive progression even though each game is pretty quick.Early game for us the monster player felt a bit too weak if they do not have AI to support (AI is very dull - some ways incredible other absolutely stupid) and initial monster choices are very poor so you just have to grind them down with traps and attrition unless you have a flying eyeball - all hail the flying eyeball!The game does a great job of sorting itself out by linking player progress to your monster evolution and becomes a pretty tense duel around the mid game, (or more reason to disrupt your coop partner irl) so maybe it will be optimised around 4 player but dont let that stop you if you have no interest in bots and often play with less people. The biggest critisisms of course is the current monster balancing and few unique path choices on their growth, this is what makes a game meaningful and replayable, its not quite there yet but this is where its going to grow I imagine. Online multiplayer and a console release would make this instant indie GOTY and print money, as it is an absolutely incredible game that everyone should buy!

Posted: November 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								One of the best local multiplayer games I have ever played, perhaps the best if I exclude tekken nostalgia. The core idea of this game is just THAT good. And it is executed brilliantly. Easy to pick up and play, it thrusts up to four players into a dungeon full of traps and doors to the unknown. One player is always the human, trying to stay alive and gain levels by fighting monsters. The monsters, however, are controlled by your "friends" - many rooms have pentagrams on the floor, which, when approached by a ghost player, allow the summoning of a ghastly creature from the depths. As the player character gains strength, the monster players gain "wrath" - which in turn allows them to upgrade their monsters to a new, unique form. This way, the 1-3 players that are not currently the human constantly gain strength, which usually means it's just a matter of time until the human falls...And when he does, the "ghost" that struck the final blow trades places with the human, and gains XP and gold in his stead. The goal is to reach level 10 and challenge the boss of the dungeon. If you beat him, you win. If you lose, there are 2 more tries ANY player has to get out. Else, everyone loses. After a game you unlock more items to buy, more dungeon objects to encounter and use (at your own risk..) and more deities. At the beginning of each game, each player picks a deity, which will 1) determine what base monsters / upgrade paths are available to that player and 2) what passive ability / starting item the human form of that player has. There is a lot more diversity to this game than initially meets the eye, which is great. Dungeons are also procedually genereated, the intro varies a lot- it really tries hard not to get old anytime soon.And on that it succeeds in my opinion. If you have any opportunity to get friends in on this - do it. You wont regret it. There are simple yet interesting combat mechanics to master, and every game unfolds differently, depending on deities and what the shop has to offer on each stage. It's really good. As for the early access, it's hardly noticable - I actually only remebered because of the frequent updates.

								absolutely love the game especially for it still being in alpha. I personally think this game is on an incredible track already and most people seem to want online multiplayer which would be very nice but not totally neccessary since the game works so well already. As far as imporovement I think its features, overall concepts, and objectives are all on point, I just think it needs more of the content that's already there to capture a truly randomly generated experience every time; things like new maps, new bosses, new monsters, more human equipment possibly even armor or clothing for customization/defense etc. As a fan of The Binding of Isaac, I love that feeling of starting up a new game (again) and not having a single clue what kind of map or monsters you'll be dealing with down to each individual room and item, and Crawl even in its early alpha stages with limited content nearly captures that up to par already.

Posted: September 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								If I where to describe this game in one word it would be "Epic!" Crawl is a insanely entertaining game with loads of things to explain. So I'll jump right into it. Crawl is a really fun game especailly when playing with freinds, and even if you are forever alone. Its still pretty fun ( But not for long. ) Anyway I am getting way off track here. In Crawl you either play as the human, who travels through a massive dungeon collecting gold and XP and buying tons of new weapons and sub-weapons which brings you to the final show down. With either a three-headed dragon or some weird chubby alein thing. However playing the human wont be easy because your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ freinds. ( Or CPU's. ) will be playing as ghosts trying to beat every last clump of living poo out of you. As a ghost you can posses traps to make them attack the human, which is supprisingly effective. Or you can go the more aggresive and entertaining way. Turning into a monster. Playing as the bad guy never felt so good but you wont be laughing for long, because if you are the one to deliver the finishing blow to the puny mortal. You basicly switch spots with the person you killed, so now they get to have ajolly old time chasing you around. Putting twice as much stress on you, however if you the human become level 10 and defeat the final boss. Then you unlock new stuff and earn bragging rights. So yeah... I would recomend it!

Posted: January 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								Awesome couch multiplayer game. Great music and visual imo. Gameplay is in a top down dungeaon crawling game. Main advantage it has is that it is very different compared to other couch multiplayer games. One person is the "hero" whilst others are ghosts going down levels of a dungeon. HeroThe aim of the hero is to level up to level 10, activate the portal and defeat the boss monster. The hero can also buy stuff from the black smith and store including weapons, buffs and special ability items. GhostsThe aim of the ghosts is to kill the hero and therefroe become the new hero. They do this by possessing traps and activating pentagrams to become monsters in the dungeon. The ghosts get viae points by other heroes leveling up to spend on evolving their monsters. Their is a good variety of monsters as of v0.3 with more to come. When the monsters hurt the hero they earn blood which they convert to gold to buy stuff when they are the hero.BossOnce a hero reaches level 10 they can activate a portal on a dungeon floor, with each floor's portal only allowed to be activated once, to fight the boss. The boss is controlled by the ghost players, eg one boss hass two tentacles and a head  making three control points and one boss has three different heads. If the hero dies they are shunted out. The boss can be fought three times total in a match until the games end.NO signs of online multiplayer anytime soon but I don't mind as the game has decent AI and I prefer them spend time adding more environements, creatures and bosses.In the end I would recommend this game if you want a multiplayer game such as towerfall, samurai gun, gang beasts etc mixed with dungeon crawling rouguelike gameplay and assymetric multiplayer like evolve or nintendo land games.

It feels very polished even when playing with bots and it has entertained a couch full of guests who knows how many times!If you want a fun and competetitive game for you and your friends I cannot reccomend tthis game enough!

Posted: September 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Last night I had some friends over at my place for dinner and afterwards we decided to play a round of Crawl. We had such a load of fun! We had 4 players, 2 with xbox controller, 1 with the xbox controller from the guitar hero drumkit and one (who despises controllers) on the keyboard. First they made the mandatory jokes about the pixely graphics and how it made their eyes bleed, but in the end the gameplay really made up for it. So, in this rogue-like game you are an adventurer trying to survive a maze of rooms and monsters (your friends) on a quest to defeat Kurok, the final boss. So while you are making your way through the rooms, your friends control incorporeal ghosts that can spawn monsters and possess traps. In some rooms pentagrams appear that allow a ghost to materialize into one of his monsters (randomly chosen) and try to gain back his mortality by defeating the hero. The one who delivers the final blow gets to play the hero.Overall, everyone got to play the hero for a while.. except me. But that's actually not a bad thing! Once you reach the trapdoor of a floor you get to the next stage and before starting, every player can upgrade his monsters. You get upgrade points (or "vitae") based on how many levels the other players gained, which means that if you didn't get to play the hero, you should get a lot of vitae to make your monsters a lot stronger. I really like this mechanic, but it didn't work out that well for us, since my friends still had pretty strong monsters as well (until I got the dragon, muahahah).With 4 players the game is pretty intense and we had a great laugh. I really recommend playing this game couch-coop.

Posted: November 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game revolutionizes 1v3 asymetrical gameplay by relying on an old game genre and reimagining it as a multiplayer experience. Basically, this game uses the dungeon crawler formula to pit one human or "hero" against 3 vengeful spirits. These teams are, however, not static. Ghosts can become monsters and control traps to attempt to defeat the human and steal his body for themselves.At it's core, this is  not a dungeon crawler or an asymmetrical team game, but a cut-throat free for all game (often only really seen in boardgames or table-top games) where you must work together with your fellow players whilst plotting how you want to take them down at the same time. Thus, the race to salvation begins.You need to reach lvl 10.You need to defeat the boss.You need to survive the pit.But how can you defeat the hero without working together?But are you able to defeat the boss with just the stats/equipment you have now?But why are there no female hero sprites??? #triggered #ermahgerd #triggered

Posted: November 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								Probably one of the only early access games that I would recommend anyone to buy.Fun to play alone, but even more fun with a group of friends. The mechanic of dying/killing the human is pretty unique for an arcade style game such as this and I think it was executed very well. It can become intense when you're the human low on health and three of your friends are trying to be the one to murder you.As a couple of other reviews I saw said, this game needs a bit more variety on the bosses. I think right now there is only 2 or 3. Hopefully the developers will include a few more. Also I, along with most others I think, really hope for the possibility of an online matchmaking system.Crawl is a fun little time waster by yourself, and a really fun game to spend an hour or two with your friends on the couch. I would definately recommend.

Posted: January 4
Early Access Review
								I've only played three hours of this game but lemme tell ya, it's amazing. From the monster levelling system, to the actual combat and the traps. It's one of the best local multiplayer games I've ever played; it's thoroughly enjoyable and you're not upset when you die to one of your pals. Alright, update, after TWENTY HOURS of this game I still absolutely adore it! I bought the Crawl bundle off of the Humble store and put the DRM free copy on a usb drive so I can run it off the drive (without installing it) on any computer. I'm super stoked for the official release and I wanted to adress some comments I've been seeing written by others. 1. If you think gameplay gets stale you've probably never tried out all the gods or different monsters. Early Access Review
Holy crap, this game is amazing.First of all, the pixel art is awesome, no doubt about that. Love the art style in general, it's a nice homage to the old arcade classics, while at the same time having a unique theme and atmosphere. The music is also great.In terms of gameplay, it's a really fun game. You unlock more and more things as you go, so you always have new things being introduced. But for the real fun, you need to get a bunch of friends over and just play this game. It is amazing. The mechanic that anyone who is "dead" is the monster is awesome, because it is not only fun to try out all the different monsters, traps, etc., but it also means that even after you "die", you always have something to do.I highly recommend this game and I hope you enjoy.

Posted: January 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Review Written on 25/01/2015 (Subject to change) Scroll for Pro's,Cons and Summary.Do you cherish your relationship with your friends?THEN DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!Crawl was made  with the intentions of turning even the strongest of bonds in to heated rivalries; One moment you will find yourself working with others to lower the heroes health, the next you're viciously scrambling to ensure you are the one who delivers  the final blow to take his place.Crawl offers that which seems to be a rareity in modern games: 4 player local multiplayer. Bringing back the golden days of real couch co-op. The game practically comes gift-wrapped in nostalgia, with its retro-arcade visuals,8-bit audio, two-button combat system and fast-paced gameplay.Gameplay:To begin with, you are greeted with an "Insert coin screen" where you must create a character name consisting of three letters. As simple as it sounds, it immediately welcomes you. Players  must then  select a god to worhsip. Each offering three different monsters with their own evolution path and starting conditions.The premise is simple; One player starts as the hero, who must reach level 10 by descending floors to defeat the boss and claim salvation.  Sounds easy eh? This would be the case, if you didn't have three other players , in ghost form, competing to become the hero in the process, by possessing traps, summoning monsters and deploying slimes. This makes survival as the hero extremely difficult, even more so as the other players gain "Vitae" a currency used to evolve their monsters each time the hero levels up or they draw blood from him.Fear not though! All is not lost, as each floor contains a blacksmith, where the Hero is able to spend gold they have accumilated through killing monsters, to purchase new weapons, trinkets and powers . However, getting to the shop first on each floor is essential if you want to claim all the best gear before anyone else.This is where Crawl really shines, it offers a sense of progression. The amount of purchaseable gear is satisfactory, and even after death, any itmes purchased are not lost.  The monsters don't lose out either, as between floors, players are prompted to evolve their monsters, becoming stronger and increasing their chances of killing the hero.Now, let's discuss one of my favourite aspects of the game: Bosses.Once players have reached level 10, they are able to face a boss, should they choose to do so, by entering the boss room and standing on a glyph. However, you can only have one attempt at the boss per floor, and three overall between everyone. This is when things become interesting, as you need to ensure you are well equipped for the battle, but have to accept the fact that persuing better gear always comes with the risk of dying and not becoming the hero again, allowing others to face the boss. Here's the brilliant part; Once the boss fight begins, any player who is not the hero is able to possess one of the bosses body parts such as the arms and head. Each limb will have a different attack, meaning cooperation and coordination is essential. If the hero prevails, the player wins the game, If the hero is to fail, he will be sent back to the floor with little health and the game continues. If all boss attempts have been used and the hero dies on the final attempt, it's game over. The winner being decided by whoever has accumilated the most XP during the game...Oh and the hero's character is permanently lost, although there seems to be no real penalty for this as there is nothing tying you to your character post-game. You can literally create another character with the same name straight after. To counter this, me and my buddies came up with a system where if your character dies, you can no longer use that three letter name again. Not much of a loss, but better than what the system currently offers.With the completion of each game, win or fail, you earn unlocks. Wether it be new traps, new evolutions for your monsters, weapons , tomes etc.... This adds to the games already enormous amount of replayability. (After 15 hours of play I still haven't unlocked everything!)Mechanics:The game plays best with a controller, although a mouse and keyboard is entirely useable. The two-button system is easy to use; you have a primary and secondary attack and a stick for movement, although the mouse can also used for movement; your character will move to where the cursor is pointed. I found the mouse a little more tedious and difficult to use as opposed to the gamepad. The fighting system is easy to understand, the difficulty comes from avoiding attacks and timing.  Personally, I'd like to be able to carry a ranged and a melee weapon and have another button to switch between the two. All in all, due to the simplicity of the controls, combat feels fluent and tight, with the animations complimenting and completing the system. Multiplayer:Be prepared for cursing, shouting, physical violence and possibly a heart attack-enduced death as you work extremely hard to bring the heroes health down only to have a friend steal the kill and become the hero. This game is best experienced with friends. You can of course play solo, the A.I is more than capable of providing a decent challenge, and is surpringly believeable, making human-like errors. But local couch multiplayer is the heart and soul of this game, and besides, there's no better feeling than defeating your friends and claiming salvation.Unfortunately, at the time of this review, Online multiplayer is not currently implemented. This is a shame because me and my buddies aren't always together, and we'd love to get some Crawl on when this is the case. Fingers crossed though!Another feature I would love to see in this game is Steam Workshop intergration. I'm sure modders would have a blast creating massive amounts of content. This would no doubt increase the lifespan of Crawl.Graphics and audio:Crawl is certainly a pretty game. From the intentional graphical glitches at the main menu, to the colourful displays of attacks ,traps, monsters and blood spills. The pixelated aesthetics feel right at home and sit comfortably amongst the haunting 8-bit track that accompanies them. The randomly generted dungeons  can get a little samey, but there is enough diversity to keep things interesting and the developers have confirmed that dungeon generation, music,  monsters, traps, items and a whole plethora of content will be added. IssuesNaturally, being in early access, Crawl is not without it's flaws; Ghosts being dragged too quickly from the last room into the next when the hero is running through them, sometimes resulting in the inability to utilise a room filled with traps. The occasional door refusing to let you pass or objects disappearing and reappearing. But these are problems that can easily be ironed out; over the 15 hours I've played, I had only encountered a few of these issues and rarely did they hinder the experience.Pro's:-4 playerLocal multiplayer-Progression system/RPG Elements-Brilliant premise; friends play as monsters -Fast-paced gameplay-Lot's of content-Replayiblity-Feels polished-Easy to jump straight in-Gorgeous pixel art-Strong mechanics-Low system requirements-More content to comeCons:-No Steam Workshop-No online Multiplayer-You will put Friendships to the test-Occasional bugsSummary:Crawl feels incredibly well-polished for an early access game, offering fast-paced gameplay, a unique take on the genre and a level of competitiveness that could only be achieved within it's own universe. 8.5/10  "Must Buy"

Posted: February 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Crawl is a fun and unique local multiplayer experience.  In short, it's a king-of-the-hill style dungeon crawler, with players constantly swapping roles as either the plucky hero or one of the three ghosts attempting to take them down.  The way that the ghosts team up against the human is best described as "formalized trolling."The asymmetry of play helps to keep the game fresh, as well as make differences in skill less pivotal in one's ability to enjoy the game.  While the graphics are blocky (unsurprising coming from a two-person team), the animations are superb.

Posted: November 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								Crawl has become, unexpectedly, one of my favorite games Mycobacterium smegmatis mc2155. As an indie game, it will be money well spent (privded you have people to play with for some fantastic couch co-op). Get it, its great.I own a lot of shared/split-screen games. I tend to organize a bunch of team sports, and pre-drinking is mandatory. To this end, having simple to play, local co-op games is a must for some good rowdy entertainemt. Crawl is simple to play (moderately hard to master). There are only two buttons, attack and special but the hook is that it is dynamic 3v1 set up. A 'human' player competes against three 'ghosts' to gain enough levels to be the one that challenges the boss. Ghosts inhabit monsters to kill the 'human'. The one that lands the deadly blow becomes 'human'. As 'human' players level, ghosts get currency to in turn level up their mosters. Thus, if you can't get a kill on a human and everyone levels around you, you will have more to spen on leveling monsters, ergo a higher chance of getting the kill. As monsters do damage to humans they gain currency they can use if they become human in a shop to increase their effectiveness. Once someone reaches enough power to challenge a boss, the 3 ghots comibine to controll that boss to fight. Overall, the game design is solid, unique, and super fun. If there are no monsters to inhabit, ghost characters can controll various traps and jump into items to harrass the 'human'.I've had this game for a long time and the developers are still providing updates with more monster evolutions, more items to purchas in the shop, and more trap dynamics. The only even remotely (possibly)negative thing is they have yet to add to the roster of end game bosses (currently there are only 2).While the overall this is a simple game there is a slight learning curve (mainly what are the monster attack/specials, possible human specials). There is progression (unlocking monster evolves/items), but it is pretty quick. Super casual players may be turned off by this, but overall, whenever I bust this game out, response is always positive.

Posted: November 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								Incredible game. I fully recommend buying. And if you're off-put by the lack of online multiplayer, don't be. Because playing with the AIs is basically the same experience you'd get from online multiplayer, except no lag, no cheaters, and more consistantly fun to play with enemies.The game is amazing about balance, and it makes it virtually impossible for one person to fall behind and end up not having a good time. Here's how it works:There's always one person who plays as the "Hero", with the other three (or other two or other one) playing as "Ghosts" who summon and inhabit monsters, as well as using traps and throwing objects at the player. Whoever kills the current Hero becomes the Hero, with the dead one becoming a Ghost. When the Hero levels up, each of the Ghosts gains 5 wrath. At the end of each floor, players can spend wrath to level up the monsters that they summon during the level. So if you spent most of the last floor as a Hero, you'll be stronger in that aspect, whereas your monsters will be struggling (it's generally better to have a strong human though, as that's how you actually win the game). So even if you're doing terribly and haven't killed the Hero once, you still have a decent shot since you will have the strongest monsters in the game, and so the best chance of becoming the next Hero. Ghosts also gain gold passively through their interactions with the Hero (although the Hero gets more), so weak Heroes can still afford to upgrade their gear once they get to a shop.Overall this game is just wonderfully balanced, both by the premise as a whole, and the amazing level of detail the developers have gone into to ensure that the scales never tip too far in one direction. You'll also never find a more attentive and responsive development team, just looking at their forums or their community page alone would be enough for me to buy this game, regardless of the amazing fun that it is.

Posted: February 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								The developers are little overly fond of the phrase "torn apart" and variants in their release notes.I mean it's kind of understandable. Everybody gets torn apart in this game. A lot.Oh, you might be wondering, what stops the player in the human flesh bag from just dawdling around and wasting everybody's time? You can do that but when the ghost players aren't otherwise occupied, they're always zooming back and forth gathering up ambient ectoplasm blobs which they can spend to summon slimes. Slimes are pretty pathetic but you can summon them in numbers as a distraction in larger fights and the hero doesn't get rewarded for killing them. Best of all slimes lock the doors when you summon them, which is good fun when the hero is just about to rush out of a trap room.I was surprised though, I was worried being a ghost would feel like wasted time but honestly not only is it fun to be a ghost but you still feel like you're in the running and pushing to win, and as a session progresses humanity starts flipping back and forth between people with hilarious frequencyIdk I'll write a real review later maybe, basically it's good and you should get it. It's wonderfully competitive enough that even when playing against bots you forget that you're playing against bots

Posted: February 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								* Delightfully antagonistic without being punitive - you always feel you can come back (and couch-based revenge is sweet)* Engages everyone at all times even when you're not the hero* Can be customized to suit varying skill levels and playstyles* Roguelike level design and randomness of item generation means strategies must remain dynamic* Alex Yoder's blippy-virtuoso soundtrack keeps your heart pounding as you fight tooth and claw to regain your freedom* Challenge mode gives you a great way to learn and practice each monster's playstyle* Powerhoof's choice of art style and "possessed glitchiness" leaves you with a splinter of dread & creep in your mind even after you finish playing* Great for decompressing after attending Sunday church services ;)* Among the most "feels feature-complete" Early Access titles I've played in a long time! (And they're still adding more!)

Posted: February 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								I can't remember if I have ever left a review for any game in all the years I've been on steam.  If I did, it wasn't a good enough one for me to remember.  I'm leaving one now.Simply put:  This game is awesome.  This is one of THOSE games:  Games that I break out in a party setting with my friends and we play it over and over and over.  The idea behind this game is simple enough, but there's enough under the hood to add some depth and variety that it doesn't make the game boring at all or feel repetitive.  Nothing is more satisfying in the world than closing off a room from the hero (as he tries to dash to the portal),  stealing a kill from another monster player (while already at level 10) and race into the adjacent room, open the portal, and attempt to kill the boss.This game will test friendships, no doubt.  It is worth every penny and I can't wait to see what else they add to it.  I'm not crying for lack of on-line multiplayer.  And, the game has some AI in it, so you can even play solo if you want.  (I also really like the 'drop in' / 'drop out' feature A LOT.  Very handy.)  I realize that a lot of people like that component and want it... but the magic here is playing with 3 other friends all in the same room.
